Yoruba: Oṣù méjì gbáko ni wọ́n fi kọ́ bí a ṣe ń s'oúnjẹ a sì ṣe ìbẹ̀wò sí ọjà.

English: During this period, young people learned basic cooking and healthy eating,
Yoruba: Lásìkò yìí, àwọn ọ̀dọ́ kọ́ nípa ìpilẹ̀ṣẹ̀ oúnjẹ sísè àti oúnjẹ aṣaralóore,

Yoruba: Níparí, a ṣe ìlànà ètò tí orílẹ̀ - èdè lè lò fún ìdàgbàsókè

English: Assessing Your Risks
Yoruba: Ṣíṣe Ìdíyelé Ewuù Rẹ

English: Last reviewed:
Yoruba: Ìtúnwò Ìkẹyìn:

English: Trying to protect all your data from everyone all the time is impractical and exhausting.
Yoruba: Ìgbìyànjú láti dá ààbò bo ìwífún kí ó ba máà bọ́ s'ọ́wọ́ ẹlòmíràn ní gbogbo ìgbà kò fi bẹ́ẹ̀ rọrùn.

English: But, do not fear! Security is a process, and through thoughtful planning, you can assess what’s right for you.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n, máà fòyà! Ìgbésẹ̀ ni ààbò, àti pé nípasẹ̀ àlàálẹ̀ tó p'ójú òṣùwọ̀n, o lè ṣe ìdíyelé ohun tí ó dára fún ọ.

English: Security isn’t about the tools you use or the software you download.
Yoruba: Ààbò kì í ṣe nípa irinṣẹ́ tí o lò tàbí iṣẹ́-àìrídìmú tí o gba ẹ̀dàa rẹ̀ sílẹ̀.

English: It begins with understanding the unique threats you face and how you can counter those threats.
Yoruba: Ó bẹ̀rẹ̀ pẹ̀lú ìwòye ìdẹ́rùbà ní pàtó tí ó kojúù rẹ àti bí o ṣe lè borí ìdẹ́rùbà ọ̀hún.

English: In computer security, a threat is a potential event that could undermine your efforts to defend your data.
Yoruba: Nínú ààbò ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá, ìdẹ́rùbà jẹ́ ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ kan tó lè tako akitiyan ààbò dátà rẹ.

English: You can counter the threats you face by determining what you need to protect and from whom you need to protect it.
Yoruba: O lè gbógun ti ìdẹ́rùbà tí ó bá kojúù rẹ nípa pípinnu ohun tí o nílò láti dá ààbò bò àti tani o ní láti bò ó fún.

English: This process is called “threat modeling"
Yoruba: Ìgbésẹ̀ yìí ni a pè ní "àwòṣe ìdẹ́rùbà."

English: This guide will teach you how to threat model, or how to assess your risks for your digital information and how to determine what solutions are best for you.
Yoruba: Ìtọ́nà yìí yóò kọ́ ọ bí o ṣe lè ṣ'àwòṣe ìdẹ́rùbà, tàbí bí o ṣe lè ṣe ìdíyelé ewuù rẹ fún ìwífún-ùn rẹ àti bí o ṣe lè mọ ìgbésẹ̀ tí ó tọ́ sí ọ.

English: What might threat modeling look like? Let’s say you want to keep your house and possessions safe, here are a few questions you might ask:
Yoruba: Báwo ni àwòṣe ìdẹ́rùbà ṣe lè rí? K’á ní wípé o fẹ́ dá-ààbò-bo ilé àti nǹkan-ìníì rẹ, ìwọ̀nyí ni ìbéèrè tí o lè bí araà rẹ:

English: What do I have inside my home that is worth protecting?
Yoruba: Kí ni mo ní nínú iléè mi tí ó yẹ kí n dá ààbò bò?

English: Assets could include: jewelry, electronics, financial documents, passports, or photos
Yoruba: Nǹkan-ìní lè jẹ́: ẹ̀ṣọ́, ẹ̀rọ ilé gbogbo, ìwé-owó, ìwé-ìrìnnà tàbí àwòrán

English: Who do I want to protect it from?
Yoruba: Nítorí tani ni mo ṣe fẹ́ ṣe ìdáààbòbò?

English: Adversaries could include: burglars, roommates, or guests
Yoruba: Ọ̀tá lè jẹ́: fọ́léfọ́lé, alábàágbé, tàbí àlejò.

English: How likely is it that I will need to protect it?
Yoruba: Báwo ni ó ṣe pọn dandan tó fún mi láti dáàbò bò ó?

English: Does my neighborhood have a history of burglaries?
Yoruba: Ǹjẹ́ aládùúgbò ní ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀-àtẹ̀yìnwáa ìfọ́lé?

English: How trustworthy are my roommates/guests?
Yoruba: Ǹjẹ́ alábàágbéè mi/àlejò jẹ́ olùfọkàntàn?

English: What are the capabilities of my adversaries?
Yoruba: Báwo l’agbára ọ̀táà mi ṣe tó?

English: What are the risks I should consider?
Yoruba: Àwọn ewu wo ló yẹ kí n gbéyẹ̀wò?

English: How bad are the consequences if I fail?
Yoruba: Báwo ni ìpalára yóò ṣe tó bí a bá kùnà?

English: Do I have anything in my house that I cannot replace?
Yoruba: Ǹjẹ́ mo ní nǹkankan nínú ilé tí n kò le è pààrọ̀ọ rẹ̀?

English: Do I have the time or money to replace these things?
Yoruba: Ǹjẹ́ mo ní àkókò tàbí owó láti pààrọ̀ nǹkan wọ̀nyí?

English: Do I have insurance that covers goods stolen from my home?
Yoruba: Ǹjẹ́ mo ní àǹfààní adójútòfò fún ẹrù tí a bá jí nínú iléè mi?

English: How much trouble am I willing to go through to prevent these consequences?
Yoruba: Wàhálà mélòó ni mo lè là kọjá láti fi ààbò fún ìpalára wọ̀nwọ̀nyí?

English: Am I willing to buy a safe for sensitive documents?
Yoruba: Ǹjẹ́ mo fẹ́ ra àpótí-ìpamọ́ fún ìwé tó ṣe kókó?

English: Can I afford to buy a high-quality lock?
Yoruba: ṣe mo lè ra ojúlówó àgádángodo bí?

English: Do I have time to open a security box at my local bank and keep my valuables there?
Yoruba: Ǹjẹ́ mo ní ààyè láti ṣí àpótí ààbò sílé ìfowópamọ̀ fún ìkópamọ́ nǹkan owó iyebíyeè mi?

English: Once you have asked yourself these questions, you are in a position to assess what measures to take.
Yoruba: Ní kété tí o bá ṣe ìbéèrè wọ̀nyí, ó ní ààyè láti díyelé ọ̀nà tí o ó gbà.

English: If your possessions are valuable, but the risk of a break-in is low, then you may not want to invest too much money in a lock.
Yoruba: Bí nǹkan-ìníì rẹ bá jẹ́ iyebíye, ṣùgbọ́n ewu ìfọwọ́lé dínkù, o lè máà fẹ́ náwó tó pọ̀ sórí àgádángodo.

English: But, if the risk is high, you’ll want to get the best lock on the market, and consider adding a security system.
Yoruba: Àmọ́, bí ewú bá gara tó bẹ́ẹ̀, o máa fẹ́ ra àgádángodo tó ń bẹ lọ́jà, àti ríra ẹ̀rọ ìdáààbòbò.

English: Building a threat model will help you to understand threats that are unique to you and to evaluate your assets, your adversaries, and your adversaries' capabilities, along with the likelihood of risks you face.
Yoruba: Kíkọ́ àwòṣe ìdẹ́rùbà yóò mú ọ lóye ìbẹ̀rù tí ó bá ọ mu àti láti ṣ'àyẹ̀wò nǹkan-ìníì rẹ, ọ̀táà rẹ àti akitiyan ọ̀táà rẹ, pẹ̀lú irú ewu tí ó ń kojúù rẹ.

English: What is threat modeling and where do I start?
Yoruba: Kín ni àwòṣe ìdẹ́rùbà àti níbo ni kí n ti bẹ̀rẹ̀?

English: Threat modeling helps you identify threats to the things you value and determine from whom you need to protect them. When building a threat model, answer these five questions:
Yoruba: Àwòṣe ìdẹ́rùbà á ràn ọ́ lọ́wọ́ láti dá ìdẹ́rùbàni mọ̀ àti pé yóò tọ́ka sí ẹni tí ó yẹ kí o pa araà rẹ mọ́ fún. Bí o bá ń kọ́ àwòṣe ìdẹ́rùbà, dáhùn ìbéèrè márùn-ún wọ̀nyí :

English: 1.What do I want to protect?
Yoruba: 1. Kí ni mo fẹ́ fi ààbò bò?

English: 2.Who do I want to protect it from?
Yoruba: 2. Ta ni mo fẹ́ pa á mọ́ fún?

English: 3.How bad are the consequences if I fail?
Yoruba: 3. Báwo ni ìpalára yóò ṣe tó bí n kò bá dá ààbò bò ó?

English: 4.How likely is it that I will need to protect it?
Yoruba: 4. Báwo ló ṣe jẹ́ kókó fún mi láti dá ààbò bò ó?

English: 5.How much trouble am I willing to go through to try to prevent potential consequences?
Yoruba: 5. Wàhálà mélòó ni mo lè là kọjá láti máà jẹ́ kí ìpalára ó wáyé?

English: Let’s take a closer look at each of these questions.
Yoruba: Kí a gbé ìbéèrè yìí yẹ̀ wò fínnífínní.

English: What do I want to protect?
Yoruba: Kí ni mo fẹ́ dá ààbò bò?

English: An “asset” is something you value and want to protect.
Yoruba: Ohun-ìní ni ohun tí ó jẹ́ ti iyebíye tí a sì fẹ́ dá ààbò bò.

English: In the context of digital security, an asset is usually some kind of information.
Yoruba: Ní ti ààbò ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá, ohun-ìní jẹ́ oríṣi ìwífún kan.

English: For example, your emails, contact lists, instant messages, location, and files are all possible assets.
Yoruba: Fún àpẹẹrẹ, ímeèlì rẹ, alábàáṣe, iṣẹ́-ìjẹ́ esẹ̀kẹ̀sẹ̀, agbègbè rẹ àti fáìlì rẹ jẹ ohun-ìní tó ṣe kókó.

English: Your devices may also be assets.
Yoruba: Ohun-ìní ni ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá rẹ náà.

English: Make a list of your assets: data that you keep, where it’s kept, who has access to it, and what stops others from accessing it.
Yoruba: Ka ohun-ìníì rẹ sílẹ̀: dátà tí o kọ pamọ́, ibi tí o kó o pamọ́ sí, ẹni tí ó lè lò ó àti àsémọ́ tí ò ní fi àyè gba ẹlòmíràn láti lò ó.

English: Who do I want to protect it from?
Yoruba: Ta ni mo fẹ́ fi pamọ́ fún?

English: To answer this question, it’s important to identify who might want to target you or your information.
Yoruba: Láti dáhùn ìbéèrè yìí, ó pọn dandan láti dá ẹni tó lè fẹ́ takóró wọnú ìwífún-un rẹ ṣeṣẹ́ ibi.

English: A person or entity that poses a threat to your assets is an “adversary.”
Yoruba: Ọ̀tá ni ènìyàn tí ó jẹ́ ìdẹ́rùbà sí ohun-ìníì rẹ.

English: Examples of potential adversaries are your boss, your former partner, your business competition, your government, or a hacker on a public network.
Yoruba: Àpẹẹrẹ ọ̀tá ni ọ̀gáà rẹ, olólùfẹ́ẹ̀ rẹ ti tẹ́lẹ̀, oníṣòwò ẹlẹgbẹ́ẹ rẹ̀, ìjọbaà rẹ, tàbí olè orí-ayélujára lórí ìṣàsopọ̀ gbogboògbò.

English: Make a list of your adversaries, or those who might want to get ahold of your assets.
Yoruba: Ṣe àkàsílẹ̀ ọ̀táà rẹ, tàbí àwọn tó máa fẹ́ jí ohun-ìníì rẹ.

English: Your list may include individuals, a government agency, or corporations.
Yoruba: Àkàsílẹ̀ẹ rẹ lè ní ẹnìkọ̀ọ̀kan, àjọ ìjọba, tàbí àjọ-ìlú.

English: Depending on who your adversaries are, under some circumstances this list might be something you want to destroy after you’re done threat modeling.
Yoruba: Ó ní íṣe pẹ̀lú ọ̀táà rẹ, nígbà mìíràn àkàsílẹ̀ yìí lè jẹ́ ohun tí ó fé mú ṣe ìparun lẹ́yìn tí o bá ti ṣe àwòṣe ìdẹ́rùbà.

English: How bad are the consequences if I fail?
Yoruba: Báwo ni ìpalára ṣe burú tó bí n bá kùnà?

English: There are many ways that an adversary can threaten your data.
Yoruba: Ọ̀ná pọ̀ tí ọ̀tá lè dẹ́rùba dátà rẹ.

English: For example, an adversary can read your private communications as they pass through the network, or they can delete or corrupt your data.
Yoruba: Fún àpẹẹrẹ, ọ̀tá lè ka ìtàkùrọ̀sọ ìkọ̀kọ̀ rẹ bí wọ́n bá wà lórí ìṣàsopọ̀, tàbí kí wọ́n pa dátà rẹ tàbí bà á jẹ́.

English: The motives of adversaries differ widely, as do their attacks.
Yoruba: Ètè ọ̀tá yàtọ̀ síra wọn, bẹ́ẹ̀ náà ni ìdojúkọ wọn.

English: A government trying to prevent the spread of a video showing police violence may be content to simply delete or reduce the availability of that video.
Yoruba: Ìjọba tó ń gbìyànjú láti pa àwòrán fídíò ọlọ́pàá tó ṣìṣe rẹ́ le jẹ ohun láti parun tàbí dín ìṣàbápàdée rẹ̀ kù.

English: In contrast, a political opponent may wish to gain access to secret content and publish that content without you knowing.
Yoruba: Ìdàkejì, olóṣèlú kejì lè rí ìwífún jí tí yóò sì tẹ̀ ẹ́ jáde, o ò sì ní mọ̀.

English: Threat modeling involves understanding how bad the consequences could be if an adversary successfully attacks one of your assets.
Yoruba: Àwòṣe ìdẹ́rùbani ní í ṣe pẹ̀lú ìwòye bí ìpalára ṣe lè rí bí ọ̀tá bá yege níbi ìkọlù ohun-ìníì rẹ.

English: To determine this, you should consider the capability of your adversary.
Yoruba: Láti mọ èyí, o ní láti gbé ipá ọ̀táà rẹ wò.

English: For example, your mobile phone provider has access to all your phone records and thus has the capability to use that data against you.
Yoruba: Fún àpẹẹrẹ, ilé-iṣẹ́ ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ọ ní àkọsílẹ̀ gbogbo ìtàkùrọ̀sọọ̀ rẹ ní àrọ́wọ́tó àti pé wọ́n lè lo àkọsílẹ̀ yìí fún iṣẹ́ẹ láabi.

English: A hacker on an open Wi-Fi network can access your unencrypted communications.
Yoruba: Olè orí ẹ̀rọ ayélujára lè fi ìṣàsopọ̀  WiFi ṣíṣísílẹ̀ r’áàyè wọ ìtàkùrọ̀sọọ̀ rẹ tí a kò yí-dátà-padà-sí-odù-ààbò.

English: Your government might have stronger capabilities.
Yoruba: Ìjọbaà rẹ lè ní ààyè tí ó lágbára láti ṣèyí.

English: Write down what your adversary might want to do with your private data.
Yoruba: Kọ ète àti àwọn ohun tí ọ̀táà rẹ lè fẹ́ fi dátà ìkọ̀kọ̀ rẹ ṣe sílẹ̀.

English: How likely is it that I will need to protect it?
Yoruba: Kí ni atọ́ka wípé n óò ní láti dá ààbò bò ó?

English: Risk is the likelihood that a particular threat against a particular asset will actually occur.
Yoruba: Ewu jẹ́ atọ́ka wípé ìdẹ́rùbà kan ṣì ohun-ìní kan yóò wáyé.

English: It goes hand-in-hand with capability.
Yoruba: Ó bá ìpójú òṣùwọ̀n mu.

English: While your mobile phone provider has the capability to access all of your data, the risk of them posting your private data online to harm your reputation is low.
Yoruba: Bí ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ọ alágbèékáà rẹ ṣe pé ojú òṣùwọ̀n tó láti lo dátà rẹ gbogbo, ewu gbígbé dátà ìkọ̀kọ̀ rẹ sí gbangba lórí ayélujára láti ṣàkóbá fún ọ bíntín.

English: It is important to distinguish between threats and risks.
Yoruba: Ó pọn dandan láti ṣe ìyàsọ́tọ̀ láàárín ìdẹ́rùbà àti ewu.

English: While a threat is a bad thing that can happen, risk is the likelihood that the threat will occur.
Yoruba: Nígbà tí ìdẹ́rùbà jẹ́ nǹkan aburú tí ó lè ṣẹlẹ̀, ewú jẹ́ atọ́ka wípé ìdẹ́rùbà yóò wáyé.

English: For instance, there is a threat that your building might collapse, but the risk of this happening is far greater in San Francisco (where earthquakes are common) than in Stockholm (where they are not).
Yoruba: Fún àlàyé, ó ní ìdẹ́rùbà wípé iléè rẹ yóò wó lulẹ̀, ṣùgbọ́n ewu yìí pọ̀ ní San Francisco (níbi tí ìṣẹ́lẹ̀ ilẹ mímì ti wọ́pọ̀) ju Stockholm (tí ò sí ìṣẹ́lẹ̀).

English: Conducting a risk analysis is both a personal and a subjective process; not everyone has the same priorities or views threats in the same way.
Yoruba: Ṣíṣe àyẹ̀wò ewu jẹ́ ìgbésẹ̀ olúkálùkù; gbogbo ènìyàn kọ́ ló ní ìṣáájú kan náà tàbí ìwò ìdẹ́rùbà lójú wò kan náà.

English: Many people find certain threats unacceptable no matter what the risk, because the mere presence of the threat at any likelihood is not worth the cost.
Yoruba: Ọ̀pọ̀ ènìyàn kì í gba àwọn ìdẹ́rùbà kan, kò sí bí ewu náà ò báà ṣe rí, nítorí ìwà ìdẹ́rùbà nígbàkugbà kò dára rárá.

English: In other cases, people disregard high risks because they don't view the threat as a problem.
Yoruba: Nígbà mìíràn, àwọn èèyàn á máa ṣe àìkàsí ewu ńlá nítorí wọ́n kò rí ìdẹ́rùbà gẹ́gẹ́ bí ìṣòro.

English: Write down which threats you are going to take seriously, and which may be too rare or too harmless (or too difficult to combat) to worry about.
Yoruba: Kọ ìdẹ́rùbà tí o ní láti mú ní òkúnkúndùn, àti t'ó sunwọ̀n tàbí t'ó léwu tó bẹ́ẹ̀ (tàbí tí ó nira láti kọju) láti yọra ẹni lẹ́nu lé lórí.

English: How much trouble am I willing to go through to try to prevent potential consequences?
Yoruba: Ìyọnu mélòó ni mo lè là kọjá láti máà jẹ́ kí ìpalára ó wáyé?

English: Answering this question requires conducting the risk analysis.
Yoruba: Ìdáhùn sí ìbéèrè yìí nílòo àyẹ̀wò ewu.

English: Not everyone has the same priorities or views threats in the same way.
Yoruba: Gbogbo èèyàn kọ́ ló ní ìṣáájú tàbí ìrí ìdẹ́rùbà lọ́nà kan náà.

English: For example, an attorney representing a client in a national security case would probably be willing to go to greater lengths to protect communications about that case, such as using encrypted email, than a mother who regularly emails her daughter funny cat videos.
Yoruba: Fún àpẹẹrẹ, aṣojú oníbàárà ní ìgbẹ́jọ́ ààbò ìjọba àpapọ̀ máa fẹ́ ṣe ju bó ṣe yẹ lọ láti dá ààbò bo ìjùmọ̀sọ̀rọ̀  ẹjọ́ náà, nípa lílo ímeelì ìyí-dátà-padà-sí-odù-ààbò, ju ìyá tí ó máa ń fi iṣẹ́-ìjẹ́ ímeelì àwòrán ológbò aláwàdà ránṣẹ́ sí ọmọ rẹ̀ obìnrin ní gbogbo ìgbà.

English: Write down what options you have available to you to help mitigate your unique threats.
Yoruba: Kọ ìyàn tí o ní láti fi gbógunti ìdẹ́rùbà rẹ sílẹ̀.

English: Note if you have any financial constraints, technical constraints, or social constraints.
Yoruba: Ṣàkíyèsí bí o bá ní ìfàsẹ́yìn owó, ìfàsẹ́yìn ẹ̀rọ, tàbí ìfàsẹ́yìn ìkẹ́gbẹ́.

English: Threat modeling as a regular practice
Yoruba: Ìṣe àwòṣe ìdẹ́rùbà olóòrékóòrè

English: Keep in mind your threat model can change as your situation changes.
Yoruba: Fi sọ́kàn wípé àwòṣe ìdẹ́rùbà lè yí padà nípa ìgbàtàkókò.

English: Thus, conducting frequent threat modeling assessments is good practice.
Yoruba: Sí bẹ́ẹ̀, ìṣàgbéyẹ̀wò àwòṣe ìdẹ́rùbà lóòrèkóòrè jẹ ìṣe tó dára.

English: Create your own threat model based on your own unique situation.
Yoruba: Ṣẹ̀dáa àwòṣe ìdẹ́rùbà tìrẹ fún ìrẹ.

English: Then mark your calendar for a date in the future.
Yoruba: Fa ilà sórí kàlẹ́ńdà rẹ fún ọjọ́ iwájú.

English: This will prompt you to review your threat model and check back in to assess whether it’s still relevant to your situation.
Yoruba: Èyí yóò ta ọ́ l'ólobó láti ṣe àtúnyẹ̀wò àwòṣe ìdẹ́rùbàà rẹ àti láti yẹ̀ ẹ́ wò bóyá ó ṣì wúlò fún ọ gẹ́gẹ́ bí òǹlò.

English: Protecting Yourself on Social Networks
Yoruba: Dídáààbò Araà rẹ lórí Ẹ̀rọ-alátagbà

English: Social networks are among the most popular websites on the Internet.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀rọ-alátagbà jẹ́ ọ̀kan lára ìbùdó-ìtàkùn lórí ẹ̀rọ-ayélujára.

English: Facebook has over a billion users, and Instagram and Twitter have hundreds of millions of users each.
Yoruba: Facebook ní bílíọ̀nù èèyàn tó ń lò ó, àti Instagram àti Twitter ní ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún mílíọ̀nù èèyàn tó ń lò ó.

English: Social networks were generally built on the idea of sharing posts, photographs, and personal information.
Yoruba: A gbé ẹ̀rọ-alátagbà kalẹ̀ fún pínpín àyọkà, àwòrán àti ìwífún nípa ara ẹni.

English: Now they have also become forums for organizing and speech.
Yoruba: Ní báyìí ó ti di ibi-ìpéjọ fún ìkójọ àti ọ̀rọ̀.

English: Thus, the following questions are important to consider when using social networks: How can I interact with these sites while protecting myself?
Yoruba: Báyìí, ìbéèrè wọ̀nyí ṣe kókó bí a bá ń lo ẹ̀rọ-alátagbà: Báwo ni mo ṣe lè lo ẹ̀rọ-alátagbà wọ̀nyí nípasẹ̀ bẹ́ẹ̀ dáàbò araà mi?

English: My basic privacy?
Yoruba: Ibi-ìkọ̀kọ̀ mi?

English: My identity?
Yoruba: Ìdánimọ̀ọ mi?

English: My contacts and associations?
Yoruba: Ọ̀rẹ́ àti alábàáṣe?

English: What information do I want keep private and who do I want to keep it private from?
Yoruba: Ìwífún wo ni kí n tọ́jú pamọ́ àti pé ta ni kí n tọ́júu rẹ̀ pamọ́ fún?

English: Depending on your circumstances, you may need to protect yourself against the social network itself, against other users of the site, or both
Yoruba: Ó dá lórí ohun ṣíṣe, ó lè nílò láti dáàbòbo araà rẹ láti de ẹ̀rọ-alátagbà fúnra rẹ̀, òǹlò mìíràn lórí ibùdó náà, tàbí méjèèjì

English: Tips to Keep in Mind When Creating an Account
Yoruba: Olobó ohun tí ó yẹ kí o kíyèsí bí o bá ń ṣí ìṣàmúlò

English: Do you want to use your real name?
Yoruba: Ǹjẹ́ ìwọ́ fẹ́ lo orúkọ àbísọ rẹ?

English: Some social media sites have so-called “real name policies,” but these have become more lax over time.
Yoruba: Ibùdó ẹ̀rọ-alátagbà mìíràn ní "ìlànà orúkọ tòótọ́," ṣùgbọ́n èyí kò rí bẹ́ẹ̀ mọ́.

English: If you do not want to use your real name when registering for a social media site, do not.
Yoruba: Bí o bá fẹ́ lo orúkọ àbísọ nígbàtí o bá ń forúkọ-sílẹ̀ lórí ẹ̀rọ-alátagbà, máà ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀.

English: When you register, don't provide more information than is necessary.
Yoruba: Bí o bá forúkọsílẹ̀, máà fi ìwífún rẹpẹtẹ ju bí ó ṣe yẹ lọ sílẹ̀.

English: If you are concerned with hiding your identity, use a separate email address and avoid giving your phone number.
Yoruba: Bí o bá ní àníyàn láti fi ìdánimọ̀ọ rẹ pamọ́, kí o lo àdírẹ́ẹ̀sì ímeèlì tó yàtọ̀ àti kí o kọ̀ láti fi ilà ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ọ rẹ sílẹ̀.

English: Both of these pieces of information can identify you individually and can link different accounts together.
Yoruba: Ìwífún méjèèjì wọ̀nyí tó fún ìdánimọ̀ olúkúlùkù àti pé ó ṣe é so ìṣàmúlò ọ̀tọ̀ọ̀tọ̀ pọ̀.

English: Be careful when choosing a profile photo or image.
Yoruba: Ṣọ́ra bí o bá ń yan àwòrán ìdánimọ̀.

English: In addition to metadata that might include the time and place the photo was taken, the image itself can provide some information.
Yoruba: Pẹ̀lú àfikúnun mẹ́tádatà tí ó ní ìgbà, àkókò àti ibi tí a ti ya àwòrán náà, àwòrán t'òhuntìkararẹ̀ lè sọ ìwífún mìíràn.

English: Before you choose a picture, ask: Was it taken outside your home or workplace?
Yoruba: Kí o tó ó mú àwòrán, ṣe ìbéèrè: Ìta ilé ni a ti yà á ni tàbí ibi-iṣẹ́?

English: Are any addresses or street signs visible?
Yoruba: Àdírẹ́ẹ̀sì tàbí atọ́ka òpópónà hàn nínúu rẹ̀?

English: Be aware that your IP address may be logged at registration.
Yoruba: Kíyèsíi àdírẹ́ẹ̀sì IP rẹ lè ti wà lákọsílẹ̀ lásìkò ìforúkọsílẹ̀.

English: Choose a strong password and, if possible, enable two-factor authentication.
Yoruba: Yan ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé tó lágbára àti, b'ó bá ṣe é ṣe, lo ìfẹ̀rílàdí-ọlọ́nàméjì.

English: Beware of password recovery questions such as “What city were you born in?” or
Yoruba: Kíyèsára fún ìbéèrè ìgbà-padà ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé gẹ́gẹ́ bíi "Ìlú wo ni a ti bí ọ?" tàbí

English: “What is the name of your pet?”
Yoruba: "Kí ni orúkọ ẹranko-àyànfẹ́ẹ̀ rẹ?"

English: because their answers can be mined from your social media details.
Yoruba: nítorí ìdáhùn lè jẹyọ láti inú àkọsílẹ̀ lórí ẹ̀rọ-alátagbàa rẹ.

English: You may want to choose password recovery answers that are false.
Yoruba: Ó lè hùn ọ́ kí o yan ìbéèrè ìgbà-padà ìṣàmúlò tí kì í ṣe òótọ́.

English: One good way to remember the answers to password recovery questions, should you choose to use false answers for added security, is to note your chosen answers in a password manager.
Yoruba: Ọ̀nà kan tí a lè fi rántí ìdáhùn sí ìbéèrè ìgbà-padà ìṣàmúlò, bí o bá yàn láti lo ìdáhùn tí ò jẹ́ òótọ́ fún àfikún ààbò, kọ ìdáhùn sí ìbéèrè pamọ́ sínúu alábòójútó ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé.

English: Check the Social Media Site's Privacy Policy
Yoruba: Yẹ Òfin Ìlànà Ibi-ìkọ̀kọ̀ Ẹ̀rọ-alátagbà wò

English: Information stored by third parties is subject to their own policies and may be used for commercial purposes or shared with other companies, like marketing firms.
Yoruba: Ìwífún tí ẹnìkẹ́ta kó pamọ́ jẹ́ fún lílòo rẹ àti pé ó lè lò ó fún ti òwò tàbí kí o pín-in fún ilé-iṣẹ́ mìíràn, bíi ilé-iṣẹ́ ìpòlówó ọjà.

English: While reading privacy policies is a near-impossible task, you may want to read the sections that describe how your data is used, when it is shared with other parties, and how the service responds to law enforcement requests.
Yoruba: Níwọ̀n bí kíka ìlànà ibi-ìkọ̀kọ̀ jẹ́ iṣẹ́ tí ò fi bẹ́ẹ̀ ṣe é ṣe, ó lè fẹ́ ka abala tí ó ṣàlàyé bí a ó ṣe lo àkọsílẹ̀ rẹ, ìgbà tí a pín-in fún ẹlòmíràn, àti bí iṣẹ́ náà ṣe dáhun sí ìbéèrè agbófinró.

English: Social networking sites are usually for-profit businesses and often collect sensitive information beyond what you explicitly provide—where you are, what interests and advertisements you react to, what other sites you've visited (e.g. through “Like” buttons).
Yoruba: Èrè-jíjẹ fún okòwò ni ẹ̀rọ-alátagbà jẹ́ àti pé ó máa ń gba ìwífún bònkẹ́lẹ́ ju ohun tí a fi sílẹ̀ lọ - ibi tí o wà, ohun tí ó kan 'ni àti ìpolówó tí a fèsì fún, ibùdó tí o ti wọ̀ rí (fún àpẹẹrẹ nípasẹ̀ẹ títẹ "Fẹ́ràn").

English: Consider blocking third-party cookies and using tracker-blocking browser extensions to make sure extraneous information isn't being passively transmitted to third parties.
Yoruba: Gbèròo dídígàgà kúkíìsì ẹnìkẹ́ta àti lílo ìtànká alépa-adígàgá asàwáríkiri fún àrídájú wípé ìwífún tí ò wúlò ò bọ́ s'ọ́wọ́ ẹnìkẹ́ta.

English: Change Your Privacy Settings
Yoruba: Ṣàtúnṣe Ìṣètò Ibi-ìkọ̀kọ̀ Rẹ

English: Specifically, change the default settings.
Yoruba: Nípa ti bẹ́ẹ̀, ṣàtúnṣe sí ààtòàbáwá tí a ti ṣe sílẹ̀.

English: For example, do you want to share your posts with the public, or only with a specific group of people?
Yoruba: Fún àpẹẹrẹ, o fẹ́ pín àtẹ̀jáde sígboro fún gbogbo ènìyàn, tàbí fún ẹgbẹ́ kan?

English: Should people be able to find you using your email address or phone number?
Yoruba: Ṣe àwọn èèyàn lè ṣàwáríì rẹ bí wọ́n bá lo ímaalì tàbí ilà ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ọ rẹ?

English: Do you want your location shared automatically?
Yoruba: Ǹjẹ́ o fẹ́ kí ibi tí o wà jẹ́ pínpínká fúnra rẹ̀?

English: Even though every social media platform has its own unique settings, you can find some patterns.
Yoruba: Bótilẹ̀jẹ́pé ẹ̀rọ-alátagbà ni ìṣètò tìrẹ, o lè rí àwòṣe.

English: Privacy settings tend to answer the question: “Who can see what?”
Yoruba: Ìṣètò Ibi-ìkọ̀kọ̀ ń bẹ láti dáhùn ìbéèrè: "Ta ló lè rí ọ?"

English: Here you’ll probably find settings concerning audience defaults (“public,” “friends of friends,” “friends only,” etc.), location, photos, contact information, tagging, and if/how people can find your profile in searches.
Yoruba: Níbí lo ti ṣe é ṣe kí o rí ààtò tí ó ní í ṣe pẹ̀lú ààtò àbáwá ("gbogboògbò," "ọ̀rẹ́ ọ̀rẹ́," "ọ̀rẹ́ nìkan," abbl), ibi tí o wà, àwòrán, bí a ṣe lè kàn sí 'ni, ìsomọ́, àti bí àwọn ènìyàn ṣe lè ṣàwáríì rẹ bí wọ́n bá ń ṣe ìṣàwárí.

English: Security (sometimes called “safety”) settings will probably have more to do with blocking/muting other accounts, and if/how you want to be notified if there is an unauthorized attempt to authorize your account.
Yoruba: Ààtò ìdáààbòbò (tí a ń pè ní "ààbò") níṣẹ́ púpọ̀ láti ṣe pẹ̀lú ìdígàgá/ìpohùnmọ́ ìṣàmúlò mìíràn lẹ́nu, àti bí o ṣe fẹ́ máa gba ìfihàn bí ẹni tí ó láṣẹ láti fàṣẹ fún ìṣàmúlò rẹ bá fẹ́ pàṣẹ fún un.

English: Sometimes, you’ll find login settings—like two-factor authentication and a backup email/phone number—in this section.
Yoruba: Ìgbà míìn, o 'óò rí ààtò ìwọlé - bíi ìfèrílàdí-ọlọ́nàméjì àti àkópamọ́ ímeèlì/ilà ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ọ - nínú abala yìí.

English: Other times, these login settings will be in an account settings or login settings section, along with options to change your password.
Yoruba: Nígbà mìíràn ẹ̀wẹ̀, ààtò ìwọlé wọ̀nyí yóò wà nínú ààtò ìṣàmúlò tàbí abala ààtò ìwọlé, pẹ̀lú ìyàn ìyípadà ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé.

English: Take advantage of security and privacy “check-ups.”
Yoruba: Jẹ ànfàání “àyẹ̀wò” ìdáààbòbò àti ibi-ìkọ̀kọ̀.

English: Facebook, Google, and other major websites offer “security check-up” features.
Yoruba: Facebook, Google, àti ibùdó-ìtàkùn mìíràn bẹ́ẹ̀ ní àfifún "àyẹ̀wò ìdáààbòbò".

English: These tutorial-style guides walk you through common privacy and security settings in plain language and are an excellent feature for users.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀kọ́ amọ̀nà wọ̀nyí á fi ibi-ìkọ̀kọ̀ àti ààtò ìdáààbòbò tí ó wọ́pọ̀ nínú èdè geere àti pé ó jẹ́ ìwò-ojú tí ó dára jù fún òǹlò.

English: Finally, remember that privacy settings are subject to change.
Yoruba: Níparí, ṣèrántí wípé ibi-ìkọ̀kọ̀ lè yí padà.

English: Sometimes, these privacy settings get stronger and more granular; sometimes not.
Yoruba: Nígbà mìíràn, ààtò ibi-ìkọ̀kọ̀ ń l'ágbára sí i, ó sì wà ní èérún; kò rí bẹ́ẹ̀ nígbà mìíràn ẹ̀wẹ̀wẹ̀.

English: Pay attention to these changes closely to see if any information that was once private will be shared, or if any additional settings will allow you to take more control of your privacy.
Yoruba: Se àkíyèsí àwọn àyípadà wọ̀nyí fínnífínní láti rí i bóyá ìwífún tí ó ti wà ní ibi-ìkọ̀kọ̀ rí yóò di pínpín, tàbí bí àfikún ààtò yóò fún ọ láàyè láti ṣe àkóso ibi-ìkọ̀kọ̀ rẹ.

English: Keep Separate Profiles Separate
Yoruba: Tọ́jú Ìdánimọ̀ ìṣàmúlò lọ́tọ̀ọ̀tọ̀

English: For a lot of us, it’s critical to keep different account’s identities separate.
Yoruba: Fún ọ̀pọ̀ ènìyàn, ó pọn dandan láti ya ìṣàmúlò s'ọ́tọ̀ọ̀tọ̀.

English: This can apply to dating websites, professional profiles, anonymous accounts, and accounts in various communities.
Yoruba: Èyí ní í ṣe pẹ̀lú ibùdó-ìtàkùn fún ẹni-tó-ń-wá-ọkọ-wá-aya, ìṣàmúlò onímọ̀, ìṣàmúlò àìlórúkọ, àti ìṣàmúlò ní onírúurú ìlú orí ayélujára.

English: Phone numbers and photos are two types of information to keep an eye on.
Yoruba: Ilà ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ọ àti àwòrán jẹ́ méjì ń'nú ìwífún tí ó yẹ kí a fojú sí.

English: Photos, in particular, can sneakily link accounts you intend to keep separate.
Yoruba: Àwòrán, ní pàtàkì, lè yọ́ mínrín so ìṣàmúlò tí o fẹ́ jẹ́ ó dá wà pọ̀.

English: This is a surprisingly common issue with dating sites and professional profiles.
Yoruba: Èyí wọ́pọ̀ ní ibùdó ẹni-tó-ń-wá-ọkọ-wá-aya àti àkáùntì onímọ̀.

English: If you want to maintain your anonymity or keep a certain account’s identity separate from others, use a photo or image that you don’t use anywhere else online.
Yoruba: Bí o bá fẹ́ fi ojú pamọ́ tàbí tọ́jú ìṣàmúlò kan pamọ́ fún òmíràn, lo àwòrán tí o kò lò rí níbòmìíràn lórí ayélujára.

English: To check, you can use Google’s reverse image search function.
Yoruba: Fún àyẹ̀wò, o lè lo aṣàwárí ìyípadà àwòrán-an Google.

English: Other potentially linking variables to watch out for include your name (even nicknames) and your email.
Yoruba: Alásopọ̀ mìíràn tó lágbára tí ó yẹ kí a f'ojú sílẹ̀ fún ni orúkọọ̀ rẹ (pàápàá orúkọ ìnagijẹ) àti ímeèlì rẹ.

English: If you discover that one of these pieces of information is in a place you didn’t expect, don’t get scared or panic.
Yoruba: Bí o bá ṣàkíyèsí wípé ọ̀kan nínú ìwífún-ùn rẹ ń bẹ níbi tí o kò lérò, máà fòyà.

English: Instead, think in baby steps: instead of trying to wipe all information about you off the entire Internet, just focus on specific pieces of information, where they are, and what you can do about them.
Yoruba: Dípò ìfòyà, ronú bí i ọmọ-ìkókó: kàkà kí o pa gbogbo ìwífún-ùn rẹ rẹ́ lórí ayélujára, kàn f'ojú sí ìwífún kéékèèké kan, ibi tí wọ́n wà, àti ohun tí o lè ṣe nípa wọn.

English: Familiarize Yourself With Facebook Groups Settings
Yoruba: Mọ àpadé-àti-àludé Ààtò Ẹgbẹ́ oríi Facebook

English: Facebook groups are increasingly places for social action, advocacy, and other potentially sensitive activities, and group settings can be confusing.
Yoruba: Ẹgbẹ́ oríi Facebook ń mú ibi ìkẹ́gbẹ́, ìgbàwí àti àwọn ohun tí ó lágbára àti ààtò ẹgbẹ́ lè rí rúdurùdu.

English: Learn more about group settings and if participants are interested in learning more about group settings, work with them to keep your Facebook groups private and secure.
Yoruba: Kọ́ ìmọ̀ kún ìmọ̀ nípa ààtò ẹgbẹ́ àti bóyá akópa nífẹ̀ẹ́ sí kíkọ́ ìmọ̀ kún ìmọ̀ nípa ààtò ẹgbẹ́, ṣiṣẹ́ pẹ̀lúu wọn láti mú kí ẹgbẹ́ Facebook jẹ́ ohun ìkọ̀kọ̀ àti ààbò.

English: Privacy Is A Team Sport
Yoruba: Eré-ìdárayá alájùmọ̀ṣe ni ibi-ìkọ̀kọ̀

English: Don’t just change your own social media settings and behavior.
Yoruba: Máà kàn ṣáà yí ààtò àti ìhùwàsí ẹ̀rọ-alátagbàa rẹ padà.

English: Take the additional step of talking with your friends about the potentially sensitive data you reveal about each other online.
Yoruba: Tẹ̀síwájú kí o sọ fún àwọn ọ̀rẹ́ẹ̀ rẹ, aburú tó ń bẹ nínú kí a máa gbé nípa ara ẹni sórí ayélujára.

English: Even if you don’t have a social media account, or even if you untag yourself from posts, friends can still unintentionally identify you, report your location, and make their connections to you public.
Yoruba: Kódà bí o kò bá ní ìṣàmúlò ẹ̀rọ-alátagbà, tàbí bí o bá yọ araà rẹ ń'nú táàgì tí a fi kó ọ pọ̀ mọ́ àtẹ̀jáde, ọ̀rẹ́ ṣì lè ṣèṣì dá ọ mọ̀, jẹ́ kí ibi tí o wà di mímọ̀, kí ìsomọ́ọ̀ rẹ pẹ̀lú wọn ó jẹ́ ojútáyé.

English: Protecting privacy means not only taking care of ourselves, but also taking care of each other.
Yoruba: Kì í ṣe dídáààbò ibi-ìkọ̀kọ̀ nìkan ni ìtọ́jú ara ẹni, àmọ́ títọ́júu àwa-ara-wa.

English: Want a security starter pack?
Yoruba: O nílò ohun-ìmọ̀ ìdáààbò àkọ́bẹ̀rẹ̀?

English: 1.Choosing Your Tools
Yoruba: 1.Yíyan irinṣẹ́ẹ̀ rẹ

English: 2.Protecting Yourself on Social Networks
Yoruba: 2.Dídáààbò araà rẹ lóríi ẹ̀rọ-alátagbà

English: 3.Assessing Your Risks
Yoruba: 3.Dídíyelé ewuù rẹ

English: 4.Communicating with Others
Yoruba: 4.Jùmọ̀ pẹ̀lú àwọn elòmíràn

English: 5.Creating Strong Passwords
Yoruba: 5.Ṣe páswọọdù t’ó lágbára.

English: 6.Keeping Your Data Safe
Yoruba: 6.Fífi ìwífún-ùn rẹ pamọ́

English: 7.What Is Encryption?
Yoruba: 7.Kí ni Encryption?

English: Choosing Your Tools
Yoruba: Yíyan Irinṣẹ́ẹ̀ Rẹ

English: With so many companies and websites offering tools geared towards helping individuals improve their own digital security, how do you choose the tools that are right for you?
Yoruba: Pẹ̀lú ọ̀pọ̀ ilé-iṣẹ́ àti ibùdó-ìtàkùn tí ó ní irinṣẹ́ fún mímú ààbò ẹ̀rọ ayélujára rọrùn, báwo ni ó ṣe yan irinṣẹ́ tó dára fún ọ?

English: We don’t have a foolproof list of tools that can defend you (though you can see some common choices in our Tool Guides).
Yoruba: A kọ́ ní òǹkà irinṣẹ́ tó jọjú ń gbèsè tí ó lè dá ààbò bò ọ́ (bí ó tilẹ̀ jẹ́ pé o lè rí àwọn àṣàyàn tó wọ́pọ̀ nínú ìtọ́nà irinṣẹ́ wa).

English: But if you have a good idea of what you are trying to protect, and who you are trying to protect it from, this guide can help you choose the appropriate tools using some basic guidelines.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n bí o bá ní iyè rere ohun tí ò ń gbìdánwò láti fi ààbò bò, àti ẹni tí ò ń gbìdánwò ṣe ìdáààbòbò fún, ìtọ̀nà yìí lè ràn ọ́ lọ́wọ́ láti yan irinṣẹ́ tí a yà sọ́tọ̀ nípa lílo àwọn ìtọ́nà kan.

English: Remember, security isn't about the tools you use or the software you download.
Yoruba: Rántí, ààbò kì í ṣe nípa ti irinṣẹ́ tí o lò tàbí iṣẹ́-àìrídìmú tí o gbà sílẹ̀.

English: It begins with understanding the unique threats you face and how you can counter those threats.
Yoruba: Ó bẹ̀rẹ̀ pẹ̀lú níní òye ìdẹ́rùbà tí ò ń kojú àti bí o ṣe lè lòdì sí ìdẹ́rùbà wọ̀nyẹn.

English: Check out our Assessing your Risks guide for more information.
Yoruba: Yẹ Ṣíṣe Ìdíyelé Ewuù Rẹ Wò tiwa fún àlàyé lẹ́kùnúnrẹ́rẹ́.

English: Security is a Process, not a Purchase
Yoruba: Ìgbésẹ̀ ni ààbò, kì í ṣe ohun tí a rà

English: The first thing to remember before changing the software you use or buying new tools is that no tool or piece of software will give you absolute protection from surveillance in all circumstances.
Yoruba: Ohun àkọ́kọ́ tí ó yẹ k'á rántí kí a tó pààrọ̀ iṣẹ́-àìrídìmú tí ò ń lò tàbí ríra irinṣẹ́ tuntun ni pé kò sí irinṣẹ́ tàbí iṣẹ́-àìrídìmú tí yóò fún ọ láàbò pátápátá.

English: Therefore, it’s important to think about your digital security practices holistically.
Yoruba: Nítorí bẹ́ẹ̀, ó ṣe pàtàkì láti wòye nípa ìwà ààbò ẹ̀rọ ayélujára porongodo.

English: For example, if you use secure tools on your phone, but don’t put a password on your computer, the tools on your phone might not help you much.
Yoruba: Fún àpẹẹrẹ, bí o bá fẹ́ ẹ́ lo irinṣẹ́ ààbò lórí ẹ̀rọ-alágbèékáà rẹ, síbẹ̀ máà fi ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé sórí ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣáà rẹ, irinṣẹ́ orí ẹ̀rọ ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ rẹ lè máà ràn ọ́ lọ́wọ́ tó bẹ́ẹ̀.

English: If someone wants to find out information about you, they will choose the easiest way to obtain that information, not the hardest.
Yoruba: Bí ẹnì kan bá fẹ́ ẹ́ wá ìwífún nípa ìrẹ, ó máa yan ọ̀nà tó rọrùn jù láti rí ìwífún náà gbà dípòo ọ̀nà líle.

English: Secondly, it’s impossible to protect against every kind of trick or attacker, so you should concentrate on which people might want your data, what they might want from it, and how they might get it.
Yoruba: Lọ́nà kejì, kò ṣeéṣe láti dá ààbò bo onírúurú ẹ̀tàn tàbí àdojúkọni, nítorí náà o ní láti f'ọkàn sí irú ènìyàn tí o lè fẹ́ jí ìwífún-ùn rẹ, ohun tí wọ́n fẹ́ fi ṣe, àti bí wọ́n ṣe lè rí i.

English: If your biggest threat is physical surveillance from a private investigator with no access to internet surveillance tools, you don't need to buy some expensive encrypted phone system that claims to be "NSA-proof."
Yoruba: Bí olúborí ìdẹ́rùbà rẹ bá jẹ́ ìbojúwò ojúkorojú láti ọ̀dọ aṣèwádìí ìkọ̀kọ̀ kan tí ò rí àyè láti lo irinṣẹ́ ìbojúwò ẹ̀rọ-ayélujára, o kò nílò láti ra ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ọ owó iyebíye tí ó ń sọ ìwífún di odù fún ààbò tí ó ní "NSA-proof"

English: Alternatively, if you face a government that regularly jails dissidents because they use encryption tools, it may make sense to use simpler tactics—like arranging a set of harmless-sounding, pre-arranged codes to convey messages—rather than risk leaving evidence that you use encryption software on your laptop.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀wẹ̀wẹ̀, bí o bá kọjú ìjọba tó máa ń fi èèyàn sátìmọ́lé nítorí o lo irinṣẹ́ ìyí-dátà-padà-sí-odù-ààbò, ó fọgbọ́nyọ bí a lo ọ̀nà tí ó ní akitiyan tó bẹ́ẹ̀ - bíi títo àkójọpọ̀ odù tí ò ní ewu, àtòélẹ̀ tí yóò gbé iṣẹ́-ìjẹ́ - ju kí a fi ẹ̀rí tí ó ní éwu wípé a lo iṣẹ́-àìrídìmú ayí-ìwífún-padà-sí-odù fún ààbò lórí ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá àgbélétan.

English: Coming up with a set of possible attacks you plan to protect against is called threat modeling.
Yoruba: Gbígbé àkójọpọ̀ ìdojúkọ tí o  lọ́kàn láti fi ààbò bò ni à ń pè ní àwòṣe ìdẹ́rùbà.

English: Given all that, here are some questions you can ask about a tool before downloading, purchasing, or using it.
Yoruba: Pẹ̀lú gbogbo ìwọ̀nyí, ìwọ̀nyí ni ìbéèrè tí o lè ṣe kí o tó gba ẹ̀dà irinṣẹ́ sílẹ̀, rà á, tàbí lò ó.

English: How Transparent is it?
Yoruba: Báwo ni mímọ́ gaara rẹ̀ ti rí?

English: There's a strong belief among security researchers that openness and transparency leads to more secure tools.
Yoruba: Oníwàdìí ààbò ní ìgbàgbọ́ wípé ìṣísílẹ̀ àti mímọ́ gaara ni ó ń ṣokùnfa irinṣẹ́ ààbò lọ́pọ̀ yanturu.

English: Much of the software the digital security community uses and recommends is open-source.
Yoruba: Ọ̀pọ̀ nínú iṣẹ́-àìrídìmú tí àwọn òǹlò ẹ̀rọ ayárabíàṣá ń lò tí wọ́n sì fi òǹtẹ̀ lù ni irinṣẹ́ fún lílò.

English: This means the code that defines how it works is publicly available for others to examine, modify, and share.
Yoruba: Èyí túmọ̀ sí wípé odù tí ó fi ń ṣiṣẹ́ ń wà ní gbangba fún ẹlòmíràn láti yẹ̀wò, túnṣe, àti ṣe àtúnpín.

English: By being transparent about how their program works, the creators of these tools invite others to look for security flaws and help improve the program.
Yoruba: Nípa mímọ́-gaara irinṣẹ́ẹ wọn, oníṣọnà irinṣẹ́ wọ̀nyí fìwé pe ẹlòmíràn láti yẹ ààbò wọn wò bóyá ó kú díẹ̀ káàtó àti láti ṣe ìmúgbòrò irinṣẹ́ náà.

English: Open-source software provides the opportunity for better security, but does not guarantee it.
Yoruba: Iṣẹ́-àìrídìmú ìṣísílẹ̀ ń fún ni láǹfààní ààbò tó péye, ṣùgbọ́n èyí kò dájú.

English: The open source advantage relies, in part, on a community of technologists actually checking the code, which, for small projects (and even for popular, complex ones), may be hard to achieve.
Yoruba: Dídára iṣẹ́-àìrídìmú ìṣísílẹ̀ wà lọ́wọ́ àwọn onímọ̀ tó ń yẹ odù iṣẹ́-àìrídìmú ìṣísílẹ̀ wò, tí, fún iṣẹ́ kékeré (àti èyí tó gbajúmọ̀, tó díjú), lè nìra láti ṣe.

English: When considering a tool, see if its source code is available and whether it has an independent security audit to confirm the quality of its security.
Yoruba: Bí o bá fẹ́ yan irinṣẹ́, wò ó bóyá odùu rẹ̀ wà lárọ̀ọ́wọ́tó àti bóyá ó ní ajẹ́rìí ààbò àdáni láti fẹsẹ̀ agbára ààbòo rẹ̀ múlẹ̀.

English: At the very least, software or hardware should have a detailed technical explanation of how it functions for other experts to inspect.
Yoruba: Ó kéré jù, ó yẹ kí iṣẹ́-àìrídìmú tàbí iṣẹ́-àrídìmú ó ní àlàyé lẹ́kùnúnrẹ́rẹ́ nípa ìṣiṣẹ́ẹ rẹ̀ fún àtúnyẹ̀wò àwọn onímọ̀.

English: How Clear are its Creators About its Advantages and Disadvantages?
Yoruba: Ǹjẹ́ oníṣọnà sọ dáadáa àti àìdáa rẹ̀ yékéyéké?

English: No software or hardware is entirely secure.
Yoruba: Kò sí iṣẹ́-àìrídìmú tàbí irinṣẹ́-àrídìmú tí a lè sọ pé ààbòo rẹ̀ pé yanrantí.

English: Seek out tools with creators or sellers who are honest about the limitations of their product.
Yoruba: Wá irinṣẹ́ tí oníṣọnà tàbí òǹtà fi ìpààlà àgbéjáde wọn hàn gbangba.

English: Blanket statements that say that the code is “military-grade” or “NSA-proof” are red flags.
Yoruba: Máà dé ibẹ̀, ewu ń bẹ ni gbólóhùn lásán tó ní odù náà jẹ́ "military-grade" tàbí "NSA-proof".

English: These statements indicate that the creators are overconfident or unwilling to consider the possible failings in their product.
Yoruba: Gbólóhùn wọ̀nyí ń tọ́ka sí ìfọ̀nu tàbí àìbìkítà láti gbà wípé àgbéjáde wọn lè kùnà.

English: Because attackers are always trying to discover new ways to break the security of tools, software and hardware needs to be updated to fix vulnerabilities.
Yoruba: Nítorí adojúkọni máa ń gbìdánwò ń gbogbo ìgbà láti wá ọgbọ́n mìíràn dá fi fọ́ ààbò irinṣẹ́, iṣẹ́-àìrídìmú àti iṣẹ́-àrídìmú nílò àtúnṣe láti dí àlàfo tó ń bẹ.

English: It can be a serious problem if the creators are unwilling to do this, either because they fear bad publicity or because they have not built the infrastructure to do so.
Yoruba: Ó lè jẹ́ ìṣòro nílá bí oníṣọnà ò bá fẹ́ ṣèyí, yálà nítorí ìbẹ̀rù ìkéde àìdára tàbí nítorí wọ́n kò ì kọ́ ohun tí yóò ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀.

English: Look for creators who are willing to make these updates, and who are honest and clear about why they are doing so.
Yoruba: Wá oníṣọnà tó ṣe tán láti ṣe àtúnṣe, àti tí ó jẹ́ ẹni tó ṣe é f'ọkàn tán, tí ohun gbogbo nípa ìdí tí ó fi ń ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀ hàn gbangba gbàngbà.

English: A good indicator of how toolmakers will behave in the future is their past activity.
Yoruba: Atọ́ka pàtàkì nípa bí oníṣọnà irinṣẹ́ yóò ṣe hùwà lọ́jọ́ iwájú ni pípadà sí ìgbà àtijọ́.

English: If the tool's website lists previous issues and links to regular updates and information—like specifically how long it has been since the software was last updated—you can be more confident that they will continue to provide this service in the future.
Yoruba: Bí irinṣẹ́ ibùdó-ìtàkùn bá to ìṣòro àtijọ́ lẹ́sẹẹsẹ àti ìsopọ̀ tí yóò dárí ẹni sí àtúnṣe àti ìwífún tó wọ́pọ̀ - bí i ní pàtó bí ó ti ṣe wà láti àtúnṣe tó kẹ́yìn - ó lè dáa lójú wípé wọn yóò túbọ̀ máa pèsèe rẹ̀ bẹ́ẹ̀ lọ́jọ́ iwájú.

English: What Happens if the Creators are Compromised?
Yoruba: Kí ló ṣẹlẹ̀ bí oníṣọnà bá níjà?

English: When security toolmakers build software and hardware, they (just like you) must have a clear threat model.
Yoruba: Bí oníṣẹ́ ọnà bá kọ́ irinṣẹ́-àìrídìmú àti irinṣẹ́-àrídìmú, àwọn (gẹ́gẹ́ bí ì rẹ) ní láti ní àwòṣe ìdẹ́rùbà tó dá ṣáṣá.

English: The best creators explicitly describe what kind of adversaries they can protect you from in their documentation.
Yoruba: Oníṣọnà tó dára ré kọjá máa ń ṣàlàyé gbangba irú ọ̀tá tí wọ́n lè ṣe ìdáààbòbò lórí nínú àkọsílẹ̀ wọn.

English: But there's one attacker that many manufacturers do not want to think about: themselves!
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n ó ní adojúkọni kan tí ọ̀pọ̀ oníṣọnà ò fẹ́ ní èrò nípa: ara wọn!

English: What if they are compromised or decide to attack their own users?
Yoruba: Bí wọ́n bá ní ìjà tàbí pinnu láti kọjú òǹlòo wọn ńkọ́?

English: For instance, a court or government may compel a company to hand over personal data or create a “backdoor” that will remove all the protections their tool offers.
Yoruba: Fún àpẹẹrẹ, ilé-ẹjọ́ tàbí ìjọba lè pa á láṣẹ fún ilé-iṣẹ́ láti kó ìwífún-ti-ẹni tàbí "gba ẹ̀yìn" yọ ààbò tí irinṣẹ́ wọn fún-un.

English: So consider the jurisdiction(s) where the creators are based.
Yoruba: Wádìí sàkání oníṣọnà.

English: If you’re worried about protecting yourself from the government of Iran, for example, a US-based company will be able to resist Iranian court orders, even if it must comply with US orders.
Yoruba: Bí o bá níjayà nípa dídáààbò ìwọtìkaraàrẹ lọ́wọ́ ìjọba Iran fún àpẹẹrẹ, ilé-iṣẹ́ kan ní America yóò lè tako ìdájọ́ọ ilé-ẹjọ́ ìlú Iran, kódà bí ó bá jẹ́ gbígba òfin ìlú America.

English: Even if a creator is able to resist government pressure, an attacker may attempt to break into the toolmakers' own systems in order to attack its customers.
Yoruba: Bí oníṣọnà bá tàpá sí i ìfínnámọ́nilábẹ́ ìjọba, adojúkọni lè gbìdánwò láti wọnú ẹ̀rọ oníṣọnà irinṣẹ́ láti kọjú ìjà sí oníbàárà.

English: The most resilient tools are those that consider this as a possible attack and are designed to defend against this.
Yoruba: Irinṣẹ́ tó dára jù lọ ni àwọn tí ó rí èyí gẹ́gẹ́ bí ìkọjú tí ó lè wáyé àti wípé a ṣe wọ́n láti dá ààbò irú ìdojúkọ báyìí.

English: Look for language that asserts that a creator cannot access private data, rather than promises that a creator will not.
Yoruba: Wá èdè tí ó fi múlẹ̀ wípé oníṣọnà ò le è rí àyè láti lo ìwífún ibi-ìkọ̀kọ̀, ó sàn ju ìlérí wípé oníṣọnà ò ní rí ìwífún ẹni.

English: Look for institutions with a reputation for fighting court orders for personal data.
Yoruba: Wá ilé-iṣẹ́ tí ó ní òkìkí nípa jíjà fún ìwífún-ti-ẹni ní ilé-ẹjọ́.

English: Has it Been Recalled or Criticized Online?
Yoruba: Ṣé wọ́n ti ṣe àtúnpè tàbí dá ẹnu èébú lù ú lórí ayélujára rí bí?

English: Companies selling products and enthusiasts advertising their latest software can be misled, be misleading, or even outright lie.
Yoruba: Ilé-iṣẹ́ atàgbéjáde àti onítara tó ń ṣe ìpolówó iṣẹ́-àìrídìmú wọn tuntun lè ṣìnà, ṣini lọ́nà, tàbí parọ́ ńlá.

English: A product that was originally secure might have terrible flaws in the future.
Yoruba: Àgbéjáde tí ó ní ààbò tó péye lè ní àìmọye àṣìṣe lọ́jọ́ iwájú.

English: Make sure you stay well-informed on the latest news about the tools that you use.
Yoruba: Rí i dájú wípé ó ní ìmọ̀ kún ìmọ̀ lórí ìròyìn tuntun nípa irinṣẹ́ tí ò ń lò.

English: It's a lot of work for one person to keep up with the latest news about a tool.
Yoruba: Kò ṣe é ṣe fún ẹnìkan ṣoṣo láti mọ ìròyìn tuntun nípa irinṣẹ́.

English: If you have colleagues who use a particular product or service, work with them to stay informed.
Yoruba: Bí ó bá ní ẹkẹgbẹ́ tí ó ń lo àgbéjáde tàbí iṣẹ́ kan pàtó, bá wọn ṣiṣẹ́ pọ̀ kí o ba ní àlékún ìmọ̀.

English: Which Phone Should I Buy? Which Computer?
Yoruba: Ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ọ wo ni kí n rà? Ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá wo?

English: Security trainers are often asked: “Should I buy Android or an iPhone?” or “Should I use a PC or a Mac?” or “What operating system should I use?”
Yoruba: A máa ń béèrè lọ́wọ́ akọni ni ààbò: "Èwo ni kí n rà nínú Android tàbí iPhone?" tàbí "Èwo ni kí n lò PC tàbí Mac?" tàbí "Irú ẹ̀rọ ìṣiṣẹ́ wo ni kí n lò?".

English: There are no simple answers to these questions.
Yoruba: Kò sí ìdáhùn geere fún ìbéèrè wọ̀nyí.

English: The relative safety of software and devices is constantly shifting as new flaws are discovered and old bugs are fixed.
Yoruba: Ọpọ́n iṣẹ́-àìrídìmú àti ẹ̀rọ ayárabíàṣá ti ń sún látàrí àṣìṣe tuntun àti àtúnṣe sí ti àtijọ́.

English: Companies may compete with each other to provide you with better security, or they may all be under pressure from governments to weaken that security.
Yoruba: Ilé-iṣẹ́ lè figagbága pẹ̀lú ara wọn láti pèsè ààbò tó péye fún ọ, tàbí kí gbogbo wọn lè wá lábé ìfínnámọ́nilábẹ́ ìjọba láti sọ ààbò di òfúùtùfẹ́ẹ̀tẹ̀.

English: Some general advice is almost always true, however. When you buy a device or an operating system, keep it up-to-date with software updates.
Yoruba: Ìmọ̀ràn díẹ̀ lọ́pọ̀ ìgbá jẹ́ òdodo, síbẹ̀. Bí o bá ra ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá tàbí ẹ̀rọ ìṣiṣẹ́, máa fi àtúnṣe kún un.

English: Updates will often fix security problems in older code that attacks can exploit.
Yoruba: Àtúnṣe àfikún yìí yóò ṣe iṣẹ́ ìdáààbòbò tí ó ti mẹ́hẹ nínú odù àtijọ́ tí ìkojú lè yá lò.

English: Note that some older phones and operating systems may no longer be supported, even for security updates.
Yoruba: Ṣàkíyèsí wípé ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ọ àtijọ́ àti ẹ̀rọ ìṣiṣẹ́ lè máà wúlò mọ́, paapàá fún àfikún ààbò.

English: In particular, Microsoft has made it clear that versions of Windows Vista, XP, and below will not receive fixes for even severe security problems.
Yoruba: Microsoft ní pàtó ti fi yé pé ẹ̀dà Windows Vista, XP, àti lọ sẹ́yìn ò ní rí àtúnṣe fún àìmọye ìṣòro ààbò.

English: This means that if you use these, you cannot expect them to be secure from attackers.
Yoruba: Èyí já sí wípé bí o bá lo ìwọ̀nyí, o ò jẹ́ lérò wípé o ní ààbò lórí adojúkọni.

English: The same is true for OS X before 10.11 or El Capitan.
Yoruba: Bákan náà ló rí fún OS X kí ó tó kan 10.11 tàbí El Capitan.

English: Now that you’ve considered the threats you face, and know what to look for in a digital security tool, you can more confidently choose tools that are most appropriate for your unique situation.
Yoruba: Ní báyìí tí o ti gbé ìdẹ́rùbà gbogbo tí ó ń kojúù rẹ, àti tí o ti mọ ohun tí o ní láti yẹ̀wò nínú irinṣẹ́ ààbò ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá, o lè fi Ògún-un rẹ̀ gbáyà láti yan irinṣẹ́ tí ó dára jù lọ fún ọ.

English: Products Mentioned in Surveillance Self-Defense

English: Communicating with Others
Yoruba: Títàkùrọ̀sọ Pẹ̀lú Ẹlòmíràn

English: Telecommunication networks and the Internet have made communicating with people easier than ever, but have also made surveillance more prevalent than it has ever been in human history.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀rọ ìgbọ́rọ̀sáfẹ́fẹ́ àti ayélujára ti mú ìtàkùrọ̀sọ pẹ̀lú ẹlòmíràn rọrùn ju ti àtẹ̀yìnwá lọ, ṣùgbọ́n ó ti mú iṣẹ́ alamí gbòòrò sí i láyé tí a wà yìí.

English: Without taking extra steps to protect your privacy, every phone call, text message, email, instant message, voice over IP (VoIP) call, video chat, and social media message may be vulnerable to eavesdroppers.
Yoruba: Láì gbégbèésẹ̀ to lààmìlaka tí yóò dáàbò bo ibi-ìkọ̀kọ̀ rẹ, àwọn elétí-ọfẹ lè máa tẹ́tí sí gbogbo ìpè, àtẹ̀jíṣẹ́, ímeelì, iṣẹ́-ìjẹ́ oníwàràǹṣesà, ìpè ohun lóríi IP, (VoIP) ìtàkùrọ̀sọ àwòrán fídíò, àti iṣẹ́-ìjẹ́ ẹ̀rọ-alátagbà rẹ.

English: Often the safest way to communicate with others is in person, without computers or phones being involved at all.
Yoruba: Láyìmoye ìgbà ni ìtàkùrọ̀sọ ojúkorojú láàbò tó pé ju ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá tàbí ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ lọ.

English: Because this isn’t always possible, the next best thing is to use end-to-end encryption while communicating over a network if you need to protect the content of your communications.
Yoruba: Nítorí bẹ́ẹ̀, ohun tó dára ní ṣíṣe ni láti lo ìyí-dátà-padà-sí-odù-ààbò òpin-dé-òpin bí o bá ń tàkùrọ̀sọ lórí ìṣàsopọ̀ fún ààbò ìtàkùrọ̀sọọ̀ rẹ.

English: How Does End-to-End Encryption Work?
Yoruba: Báwo ni Ìyí-dátà-padà-sí-odù-ààbò Òpin-dé-òpin ṣe ń ṣiṣẹ́?

English: When two people want to communicate securely (for example, Akiko and Boris) they must each generate crypto keys.
Yoruba: Bí ẹni méjì bá fẹ́ tàkùrọ̀sọ tí wọn kò sì fẹ́ kí ẹnìkẹ́ta ó f'etíkó o (fún àpẹẹrẹ, Akiko àti Boris) wọn gbọdọ̀ ṣe àgbàjáde kọ́kọ́rọ́ àìrí.

English: Before Akiko sends a message to Boris she encrypts it to Boris's key so that only Boris can decrypt it.
Yoruba: Kí Akiko ó tó fi iṣẹ́-ìjẹ́ ránṣẹ́ sí Boris, ó lo ìyódùpadàfáàbò sí kọ́kọ́rọ́ọ Boris tí ó fi jẹ́ wípé Boris nìkan ló lè tú ìyí-dátà-padà-sí-odù-ààbò yìí.

English: Then she sends the already-encrypted message across the Internet.
Yoruba: Lẹ́yìn ìgbà náà ni yóó fi iṣẹ́-ìjẹ́ tí a ti yí odùu rẹ̀ padà fún ààbò ránṣẹ́ lórí ẹ̀rọ ayélujára.

English: If anyone is eavesdropping on Akiko and Boris—even if they have access to the service that Akiko is using to send this message (such as her email account)—they will only see the encrypted data and will be unable read the message.
Yoruba: Bí ẹnikẹ́ni bá ń tẹ́tí sí ìtàkùrọ̀sọ Akiko àti Boris - kódà bí wọ́n bá rí ọ̀nà wọ apèsè tí Akiko ń lò fi ṣe olùránṣẹ́ iṣẹ́-ìjẹ́ (gẹ́gẹ́ bí ìṣàmúlò ímeelìi rẹ̀) - odù tí a yí padà fún ààbò nìkan ni wọ́n máa rí, wọn kò ní lè ka iṣẹ́-ìjẹ́ náà.

English: When Boris receives it, he must use his key to decrypt it into a readable message.
Yoruba: Bí Boris bá gbà á, ó ní láti lo kọ́kọ́rọ́ọ rẹ̀ láti fi tú u kí ó bá jẹ́ rírí kà.

English: End-to-end encryption involves some effort, but it's the only way that users can verify the security of their communications without having to trust the platform that they're both using.
Yoruba: Ìyódùpadàfáàbò òpin-dé-òpin gba akitiyan tó pọ̀, ṣùgbọ́n ó jẹ́ ọ̀nà kan ṣoṣo tí òǹlò fi lè ṣ'àyẹ̀wò ààbò ìtàkùrọ̀sọ láì ṣiyèméjì nípa ààbò gbàgede tí wọ́n ń lò.

English: Some services, such as Skype, have claimed to offer end-to-end encryption when it appears that they actually don't.
Yoruba: Ìpèsè mìíràn, bíi Skype, fi yé wípé òun ń lo ìyódùpadàfáàbò òpin-dé-òpin síbẹ̀ ó jọ wípé wọn kò lò ó.

English: For end-to-end encryption to be secure, users must be able to verify that the crypto key they're encrypting messages to belongs to the people they believe they do.
Yoruba: Kí ìyódùpadàfáàbò òpin-dé-òpin ó tó ó ṣiṣẹ́ dáadáa, òǹló gbọdọ̀ ní aṣàyẹ̀wò tí yóó tú àṣìírí bóyá kọ́kọ́rọ́ àìrí tí wọn ń fi ń ṣe ìyódùpadàfáàbò iṣẹ́-ìjẹ́ jẹ́ ti ẹni tó yẹ kí ó jẹ́.

English: If communications software doesn't have this ability built-in, then any encryption that it might be using can be intercepted by the service provider itself, for instance if a government compels it to.
Yoruba: Bí iṣẹ́-àìrídìmú ìtàkùrọ̀sọ ò bá leè ṣe irú iṣẹ́ yìí, èyíkéyìí ìyí-dátà-padà-sí-odù-ààbò tí ó lè máa lò lè ní ìkọlù apèsè gan-an, bóyá bí ìjọba bá pa á láṣẹ láti ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀.

English: You can read Freedom of the Press Foundation's whitepaper, Encryption Works for detailed instructions on using end-to-end encryption to protect instant messages and email.
Yoruba: O lè ka ìwé àpilẹ̀kọ Freedom of the Press Foundation, ìyí-dátà-padà-sí-odù-ààbò ṣiṣẹ́ fún ẹ̀kúnrẹ́rẹ́ àṣẹ lóríi bí a ṣe ń lo ìyódùpadàfáàbò òpin-dé-òpin fún ààbò iṣẹ́-ìjẹ́ oníwàràǹṣesà àti ímeelì.

English: Voice Calls
Yoruba: Ìpè Ohun

English: When you make a call from a landline or a mobile phone, your call is not end-to-end encrypted.
Yoruba: Bí o bá ń pè lóríi ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ọ oríi tábìlì tàbí lóríi ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ọ alágbèéká, a kò lo yí-dátà-rẹ̀-padà-sí-odù-ààbò òpin-dé-òpin fún ìpè rẹ.

English: If you're using a mobile phone, your call may be (weakly) encrypted between your handset and the cell phone towers.
Yoruba: Bí o bá ń lo ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ọ alágbèéká, ẹ̀rọ-ìléwọ́ àti òpó agbáfẹ́fẹ́-ọ̀rọ̀-ká lè máa lágbára tó lórí ìpèè rẹ.

English: However as your conversation travels through the phone network, it's vulnerable to interception by your phone company and, by extension, any governments or organizations that have power over your phone company.
Yoruba: Síbẹ̀ bí ìtàkùrọ̀sọọ̀ rẹ bá gba ìṣàsopọ̀ kọjá, o lè ní ìkọlù láti apá ilé-iṣẹ́ ìṣàsopọ̀ ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ àti pẹ̀lú ìtànká, ìjọbakíjọba tàbí àjọ tí ó ní agbára lóríi ilé-iṣẹ́ ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ọ rẹ.

English: The easiest way to ensure you have end-to-end encryption on voice conversations is to use VoIP instead.
Yoruba: Ọ̀nà tó rọrùn jù lọ fún àrídájú ìyí-dátà-padà-sí-odù-ààbò òpin-dé-òpin lórí ìtàkùrọ̀sọ ohun ni láti lo VoIP.

English: Beware! Most popular VoIP providers, such as Skype and Google Hangouts, offer transport encryption so that eavesdroppers cannot listen in, but the providers themselves are still potentially able to listen in.
Yoruba: Kíyèsára! Àwọn apèsè VoIP tó jẹ́ gbajúmọ̀, gẹ́gẹ́ bíi Skype àti Google Hangout, máa ń lo ìyí-dátà-padà-sí-odù-ààbò ìṣíkúrò kí àwọn atẹ́tí sí ìtàkùrọ̀sọ ó máà le è gbọ́, àmọ́ṣá apèsè tìkára wọn lè máa gbọ́.

English: Depending on your threat model, this may or may not be a problem.
Yoruba: Ó dá lórí, àwòṣe ìdẹ́rùbà rẹ, èyí lè jẹ́ ìṣòro, ó sì lè máà jẹ́sòro.

English: In order to have end-to-end encrypted VoIP conversations, both parties must be using the same (or compatible) software.
Yoruba: Fún ìtàkùrọ̀sọ VoIP tí a ti yí dátà rẹ̀ padà sí odùu fún ààbò, ẹni méjèèjì tó ń tàkùrọ̀sọ gbọdọ̀ lo iṣẹ́-àìrídìmú kan náà (tàbí èyí tí ó bára wọn mu).

English: Standard text (SMS) messages do not offer end-to-end encryption.
Yoruba: Àtẹ̀jíṣẹ́ tí a mọ̀ bí ẹní m'ọwọ́ (SMS) ò lo ìyí-dátà-padà-sí-odù-ààbò òpin-dé-òpin.

English: If you want to send encrypted messages on your phone, consider using encrypted instant messaging software instead of text messages.
Yoruba: Bí o bá fẹ́ fi iṣẹ́-ìjẹ́ tí a ti yí dátà rẹ̀ padà sí odùu ààbò ránṣẹ́ lórí ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ rẹ, o ò ṣe lo iṣẹ́-àìrídìmú ìyí-dátà-padà-sí-odù-ààbò fún iṣẹ́-ìjẹ́ oníwàràǹṣesà dípò àtẹ̀jíṣẹ́.

English: Some end-to-end encrypted instant messaging services use their own protocol.
Yoruba: Díẹ̀ nínú àwọn iṣẹ́-ìjẹ́ oníwàràǹṣesà tí a ti yí dátà rẹ̀ padà sí odùu ààbò ìfẹ́nukò ti wọn.

English: So, for instance, users of Signal on Android and iOS can chat securely with others who use those programs.
Yoruba: Wàyí, ẹ wò ó báyìí, àwọn òǹlòo Signal lórí Android àti iOS lè sọ̀rọ̀ bótibòti pẹ̀lú ààbò lóríi gbàgede wọ̀nyí.

English: ChatSecure is a mobile app that encrypts conversations with OTR on any network that uses XMPP, which means you can choose from a range of independent instant messaging services.
Yoruba: Áàpù tí máa ń yí odù ìtàkùrọ̀sọ padà fún ààbò pẹ̀lú OTR lórí èyíkéyìí ìṣàsopọ̀ tó ń lo XMPP ni ChatSecure, tí ó túmọ̀ sí wípé ó lè ṣ'àṣàyànan nínú oríṣiríṣi iṣẹ́-ìjẹ́ àdádúró tí ó hùn ọ́ nínú àìmọye tó wà.

English: Instant Messages
Yoruba: Iṣẹ́-ìjẹ́ Oníwàràǹṣesà

English: Off-the-Record (OTR) is an end-to-end encryption protocol for real-time text conversations that can be used on top of a variety of services.
Yoruba: Ìfẹ́nukò  ìyí-dátà-padà-sí-odù-ààbò òpin-dé-òpin fún ìtàkùrọ̀sọ alátẹ̀jíṣẹ́ ojú-ẹsẹ̀ tó ṣe í lò lórí onírúurú iṣẹ́ ni Àìsí-lákọsílẹ̀ (OTR).

English: Some tools that incorporate OTR with instant messaging include:
Yoruba: Àwọn irinṣẹ́ tó ní OTR nínú pẹ̀lú iṣẹ́-ìjẹ́ oníwàràǹṣesà ni:

English: Most email providers give you a way of accessing your email using a web browser, such as Firefox or Chrome.
Yoruba: Ọ̀pọ̀ apèsè ímeèlì fún ọ láàyè láti yẹ ímeèlìi wò lórí ìtàkùn aṣàwáríkiri, gẹ́gẹ́ bíi Firefox tàbí Chrome.

English: Of these providers, most of them provide support for HTTPS, or transport-layer encryption.
Yoruba: Nínú apèsè wọ̀nyí, ìtìlẹ́yìn wà fún HTTPS, tàbí ìyí-dátà-padà-sí-odù-ààbò ìpele-ìṣíkúrò.

English: You can tell that your email provider supports HTTPS if you log in to your webmail and the URL at the top of your browser begins with the letters HTTPS instead of HTTP (for example: https://mail.google.com).
Yoruba: Ó lè mọ̀ bí apèsè ímeèlìi rẹ bá pèsè ìtìlẹ́yìn HTTPS fún ọ bí o bá wọlé sínú ìtàkùn-ímeèlì rẹ àti URL orí òkè aṣàwáríkiriì rẹ tí ó bẹ̀rẹ̀ pẹ̀lú lẹ́tà HTTPS nípò HTTP (fún àpẹẹrẹ: https://mail.google.com)

English: If your email provider supports HTTPS, but does not do so by default, try replacing HTTP with HTTPS in the URL and refresh the page.
Yoruba: Bí apèsè ímeèlì rẹ bá ní ìtìlẹ́yìn fún HTTPS, ṣùgbọ́n tí kò ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀, gbìyànjú kí o pààrọ̀ HTTP pẹ̀lú HTTPS nínú URL kí o sì tún ojúùwé náà tẹ̀.

English: If you’d like to make sure that you are always using HTTPS on sites where it is available, download the HTTPS Everywhere browser add-on for Firefox or Chrome.
Yoruba: Bí o bá fẹ́ ìdánilójú wípé HTTPS lo máa ń lò ní gbogbo ìgbà lórí ibùdó tí ó bá wà, gba ẹ̀dà àfilé HTTPS Níbigbogbo sílẹ̀ fún lílò lóríi asàwáríkiri Firefox tàbí Chrome.

English: Some webmail providers that use HTTPS by default include:
Yoruba: Apèsè imeèlì ìtàkùn àgbáyé tó máa ń lo ààtò-àbáwá HTTPS ni :

English: Some webmail providers that give you the option of choosing to use HTTPS by default by selecting it in your settings.
Yoruba: Apèsè ìtàkùn-ímeèlì mìíràn fún ọ láàyè láti yan HTTPS gẹ́gẹ́ bí àbáwá tí o lè yàn nínú ààtò rẹ.

English: The most popular service that still does this is Hotmail.
Yoruba: Èyí tó gbajúmọ̀ jù lọ ni Hotmail t'ó ṣì ń ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀ dòní.

English: What does transport-layer encryption do and why might you need it?
Yoruba: Kí ni ìyí-dátà-padà-sí-odù-ààbò ìpele-ìṣíkúrò ń ṣe àti ìdí tí o fi lè nílòo rẹ fún?

English: HTTPS, also referred to as SSL or TLS, encrypts your communications so that it cannot be read by other people on your network.
Yoruba: HTTPS, tí a tún mọ̀ sí SSL tàbí TLS, máa ń yí dátà ìtàkùrọ̀sọọ̀ rẹ padà-sí-odù-ààbò kí ẹlòmíràn ó máà bá a rí i kà lóríi ìṣàsopọ̀ rẹ.

English: This can include the other people using the same Wi-Fi in an airport or at a café, the other people at your office or school, the administrators at your ISP, malicious hackers, governments, or law enforcement officials.
Yoruba: Èyí lè kan àwọn tí ẹ jọ ń lo WiFi kan náà ní pápákọ̀ òfuurufú tàbí ní ilé ìjẹun, àwọn ẹlòmíràn ní ibiiṣẹ́ tàbí ilé ìwé, alákòóso ilé-iṣẹ́ apèsèe (ISP) rẹ, olè apanilára, ìjọba, tàbí àjọ agbófinró.

English: Communications sent over your web browser, including the web pages that you visit and the content of your emails, blog posts, and messages, using HTTP rather than HTTPS are trivial for an attacker to intercept and read.
Yoruba: Ìtàkùrọ̀sọ tí o fi ránṣẹ́ lóríi ìtàkùn aṣàwáríkiriì rẹ, títí kan ìtàkùn ojú-ìwé tí o lọ àti ohuninú ímeèlì rẹ, ìwé-ìrántí ibùdó-ìtàkùn-àgbáyé àti iṣẹ́-ìjẹ́, lílo HTTP dípò HTTPS f'ààyè gba adojúkọni láti dí ìtàkùrọ̀sọọ̀ rẹ lọ́wọ́ àti kà á.

English: HTTPS is the most basic level of encryption for your web browsing that we recommend for everybody.
Yoruba: HTTPS ni ìpilẹ̀ṣẹ̀ ìyí-dátà-padà-sí-odù-ààbò ìtàkùn aṣàwáríkiriì rẹ tí a f'ọwọ́ sí fún ènìyàn gbogbo.

English: It is as basic as putting on your seat belt when you drive.
Yoruba: Ó dàbíi síso okùn ààbò ìjókòó bí o bá ń wa ọkọ̀.

English: But there are some things that HTTPS does not do.
Yoruba: Àmọ́ ó ní àwọn ohun tí HTTPS kì í ṣe.

English: When you send email using HTTPS, your email provider still gets an unencrypted copy of your communication.
Yoruba: Bí o bá fi ímeèlì ránṣẹ́ lórí HTTPS, apèsèe ímeèlì rẹ yóò ṣì rí ẹ̀dà ìtàkùrọ̀sọọ̀ rẹ tí data ò yí odù rẹ̀ padà fún ààbò.

English: Governments and law enforcement may be able to access this data with a warrant.
Yoruba: Ìjọba àti agbófinró lè rí dátà rẹ pẹ̀lú ìwé àṣẹ.

English: In the United States, most email providers have a policy that says they will tell you when you have received a government request for your user data as long as they are legally allowed to do so, but these policies are strictly voluntary, and in many cases providers are legally prevented from informing their users of requests for data.
Yoruba: Ní ìlú America, ọ̀pọ̀ apèsèe ímeèlì ló ní ìlànà àti àkọsílẹ̀ pé wọn yóò wí fún ọ bí àwọn ìjọba bá l'áwọ̀n-ọ́n fẹ́ ẹ́ rí dátà rẹ gẹ́gẹ́ bí òǹlò, níwọ̀n ìgbà t'áṣẹ bá f'ààyè gbà wọ́n, ṣùgbọ́n ìlànà yìí kì í ṣe tipá, àti pé lọ́pọ̀ ìgbà ni òfin kò fún apèsè láyé láti sọ fún òǹlò wípé ìjọba béèrè fún dátà rẹ̀.

English: Some email providers, such as Google, Yahoo, and Microsoft, publish transparency reports, detailing the number of government requests for user data they receive, which countries make the requests, and how often the company has complied by turning over data.
Yoruba: Apèsèe ímeèlì, gẹ́gẹ́ bíi Google, Yahoo, àti Microsoft, tẹ àtẹ̀jádé ìròyìn mímọ́ gaara tó ń s'àlàyé iye ìbéèrè fún dátà òǹlò tí wọ́n ti gbà, ìlú t'ó béèrè fún un, àti iye ìgbà tí ilé-iṣẹ́ náà ti fi dátà ṣọwọ́ sí ìjọba.

English: If your threat model includes a government or law enforcement, or you have some other reason for wanting to make sure that your email provider is not able to turn over the contents of your email communications to a third party, you may want to consider using end-to-end encryption for your email communications.
Yoruba: Bí àwòṣe ìdẹ́rùbà rẹ bá ní ìjọba tàbí agbófinró nínú, tàbí o ní ìdí mìíràn fún àìfààyègba apèsèe ímeèlì láti fi ohuninúu ímeèlì rẹ ránṣẹ́ sí ẹnìkẹ́ta, o lè fẹ́ ẹ́ máa lo ìyí-dátà-padà-sí-odù-ààbò òpin-dé-òpin fún ìtàkùrọ̀sọọ̀ ímeèlì rẹ.

English: PGP (or Pretty Good Privacy) is the standard for end-to-end encryption of your email. Used correctly, it offers very strong protections for your communications.
Yoruba: PGP (tàbí Ibi-Ìkọ̀kọ̀ tó Dára Jù) ni ìyódùpadàfáàbò òpin-dé-òpin tí ó dára jù fún ímeèlì rẹ. Bí o bá lò ó lọ́nà tó yẹ, ó máa dá ààbò tó lágbára bo ìtàkùrọ̀sọọ̀ rẹ.

Yoruba: Bí a ṣe n: Lo PGP fún Mac OS X

English: What End-To-End Encryption Does Not Do?
Yoruba: Kí ni ìyí-dátà-padà-sí-odù-ààbò òpin-dé-òpin kì í ṣe?

English: End-to-end encryption only protects the content of your communication, not the fact of the communication itself.
Yoruba: Ìyódùpadàfâbò òpin-dé-òpin ń dáàbò bo ohuninú ìtàkùrọ̀sọ rẹ nìkan, kì í dáàbò bo ìtàkùrọ̀sọ tìkararẹ̀.

English: It does not protect your metadata—which is everything else, including the subject line of your email, or who you are communicating with and when.
Yoruba: Kì í dáàbò bo mẹ́tádatà - tí í ṣ'àpèjúwe ohun gbogbo nípa dátà, tí ó fi kan ilà àkórí ímeèlì rẹ, tàbí ẹni tí ó ń tàkùrọ̀sọ pẹ̀lú àti ìgbà tí o tàkùrọ̀sọ.

English: Metadata can provide extremely revealing information about you even when the content of your communication remains secret.
Yoruba: Mẹ́tádatà yìí lè pèsèe gbogbo àṣìírí nípaà rẹ nígbà tí ohuninúu ìtàkùrọ̀sọ rẹ ń bẹ níkọ̀kọ̀.

English: POISON THAT KILLS MAN
Yoruba: MÁJÈLÉ TÓ N PA ỌKÙNRIN

English: Once upon a time, a pretty woman said that her marriage with her husband is not rewarding for her, so she decided to kill her husband with poison.
Yoruba: Nígbà kan rí, arẹwà ọmọbìnrin kan ní ìgbéyàwó òun àti ọkọ òun kò yé òun mọ́, ó sì pinnu láti pa ọkọ rẹ̀ pẹ̀lú májèlé.

English: One early morning, she went to her mother to explain the matter about what she face in the house of her husband, she told her mother, that she is fed up with her husband’s behaviour.
Yoruba: Ni òwúrọ̀ kùtùkùtù ọjọ́ kan, ó tọ́ ìyá-a rẹ̀ lọ láti ṣàlàyé ọ̀ràn náà tí ojú u rẹ̀ ń rí nílé ọkọ, ó sọ fún ìyá a rẹ̀, wípé ọ̀rọ̀ ọkọ òun ti sú òun wípé òun kò lè farada ìhùwàsíi rẹ̀ mọ́.

English: The mother answered her that: Yes, my child I can be of help on this one. But there is something attached to this step.
Yoruba: Ìyá bá dá a lóhùn wípé: Bẹ́ẹ̀ ni, ọmọ mi mo lè ṣe ìrànlọ́wọ́ eléyìí. Ṣùgbọ́n ó ní nǹkan kan tó rọ̀ mọ́ ìgbésẹ náà.

English: This woman asked her mother a question that what is the step to be taken?   I am willing to take any step to ensure that I kill my husband.
Yoruba: Ọmọbìnrin yìí bi ìyá-a rẹ̀ léèrè pé kíní ìgbésẹ náà? Mo ṣe tán láti ṣe ohunkóhun láti rí i wípé mo pa ọkọ mi.

English: Secondly, you have to take good care of your body, for you to look beautiful like a baby and like a new bride in the eyes of your husband.
Yoruba: Èkejì, o ní láti máa tún araà rẹ ṣe, láti rẹwà kí o lè dá bí ọmọ kékeré àti bi ìyàwó àṣẹ̀ṣẹ̀gbèé lójú ọkọ ọ̀ rẹ.

English: Disorganisers turned history upside down. The result of their deception is the reason why they say that we do not know God until they arrive, this is how they used religion to enslave one, they call father guinea corn, they called Èṣù our deity Satan.
Yoruba: Màdàrú dojú ìtàn kodò. Arapa ète wọn náà ló fà á tí wọ́n fi ní a ò mọ Ọlọ́run káwọn ó tó dé, báyìí ni wọ́n ṣe fi ẹ̀sìn mú ni sìn, bàbá ni wọ́n pè bàbà, wọ́n pe Èṣù ní Sátánì fún wa.

English: I have one question for thinkers, if truelly we do not know God the King Owner-of-the-universe Omnipresent, then why do we have such names in the African vocabulary?
Yoruba: Mo ní ìbéèrè kan fún aláròjinlẹ̀, bí ó bá jẹ́ wípé a kò mọ Ọlọ́run Ọba Olódùmarè Atẹ́rẹrẹ-káyé, báwọ̀ la ṣe ní irú orúkọ wònyí nínú ìfọ̀ èdè abínibíì wa nílẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀?

English: Do you know that it is this God of Heaven and Earth who has the most name, every tongue has a name for Him?
Yoruba: Ǹjẹ́ ìwọ́ mọ̀ wípé Ọlọ́run Ilẹ̀ àti Òkè yìí ló lórúkọ tó pọ̀ jù lọ, gbogbo ahọ́n ló ní orúkọ tí ó mọ̀ Ọ́n mọ́?

English: If we break it down and rearrange it, Owner-of-heaven; Oní-Ọ̀run. It is elision of words in Oní-Ọ̀run makes it Ọlọ́run.
Yoruba: Ká dà á sílẹ̀ kí a tún un ṣà, O-Ní-Ọ̀-Run; Oní-Ọ̀run. Ìpàrójẹ tó dé bá Oní-Ọ̀run ni ó fi di Ọlọ́run.

English: We are certain, there is heaven, we also know that heaven existed before earth came to being, we do not say that we do not know that there is a soul mightier than all souls, we know heaven is his resident.
Yoruba: A mọ́ dájú bí ọṣẹ pé, ọ̀run ń bẹ, a sì mọ̀ wípé ọ̀run ti ń bẹ kí ayé ó tó mọ́ ọ bẹ, a ò lá ò mọ̀ wípé ẹ̀mí kan ń bẹ tó ju ẹ̀míkẹ́mìí lọ, a mọ̀ pé ní ọ̀run ni ibùdóo Rẹ̀.

English: We know that the Owner-of-the-Universe is the king and controller of heaven and earth.
Yoruba: A mọ̀ wípé Olódùmarè ni ọba aláṣẹ lọ́run àti láyé.

English: His authority makes everything come to being.
Yoruba: Àṣẹ rẹ̀ ni ohun gbogbo fi ń bẹ.

English: It is in the hands of the Owner-of-heaven Owner-of-the-universe that everything came to earth, it is with His knowledge that things on earth came to be.
Yoruba: Ọwọ́ Ọlọ́run Olódùmarè ni ohun gbogbo ti wá sáyé, mímọ̀ọ́nṣe rẹ̀ ni ohun gbogbo fi ń bẹ láyé.

English: In the exoteric Ifá Ọ̀yẹ̀kú Mogbè corpus, Ifá says
Yoruba: Nínú Odù Ifá Ọ̀yẹ̀kú Mogbè, Ifá ní

English: “The earth is a market, heaven is home, cast Ifá for the Owner-of-the-universe, if you get to earth, if you forget heaven, Earth is a market, heaven is the home of everybody, you will report, what you saw.”
Yoruba: “Ayé lọ́jà, ọ̀run nílé, a díá fún Olódùmarè baba atáyé mátu, bẹ́ ẹ délé ayé, bẹ́ ẹ gbàgbé ọ̀run, Ayé lọ́jà, ọ̀run nilé ẹ̀yin èrò, ẹ ó jíyìn, ẹ ó jábọ̀, ohun tí ẹ rí.”

English: An explanation of how the Owner-of-heaven Owner-of-the-universe created earth just like a market which humans visit is what this Ifá verse is saying.
Yoruba: Alààyè bí Ọlọ́run Olódùmarè ṣe dá ayé gẹ́gẹ́ bí ọjà tí ọmọ aráyé wá ná ni ẹsẹ̀ Ifá yìí ń sọ fún wa.

English: When the Owner-of-the-universe sent Ọ̀rúnmìlà to earth, he scattered wisdom on earth, some people saw the wisdom that the Owner-of-the-universe scattered all over the earth, they picked it.
Yoruba: Nígbà tí Elédùà rán Ọ̀rúnmìlà wá sáyé, ó da ọgbọ́n sílé ayé, àwọn kan rí ọgbọ́n tí Olódùmarè fún Ọ̀rúnmìlà láti dà sílẹ̀ láyé, wọ́n sì ṣà á.

English: He-sees-it-to-pick, one who sees wisdom to pick on earth, he that performed greatly while on earth, becomes òrìṣà that men venerate after death.
Yoruba: Ó-rí-i-ṣà, ẹni tí ó rí ọgbọ́n ṣà nílé ayé, tí ó dábírà nígbà tí ó ń bẹ lórí lẹ̀ alàyè, ni ó di òrìṣà ténìyàn ńbọ lẹ́yìn ikú.

English: Their attitude, their behaviour, their character and ways of life is what human beings want to imitate.
Yoruba: Ìwà wọn, ìwùwàsí wọn, ìṣe wọn àti ìgbé ayé wọn ni àwọn èèyàn abìdíyànyàn ma ń fẹ́ wò kọ́ ṣe.

English: In Yorùbáland, the wise one are accorded respect, including brave and warriors, hunters, men of mysteries and everyone that is a professional is given reverence.
Yoruba: Ní ilẹ̀ Yorùbá, àwọn ọlọ́gbọ́n inú ẹ̀dá ni a máa ń gbóríyìn fún, pẹ̀lú àwọn akínkanjú èèyàn àti akọni jagunjagun, ọdẹ, awo tí ó gbójú gbóyà tí ó dájú nínú iṣẹ́ẹ rẹ̀.

English: In the ancient times, Yorùbáland has enormous number of intelligent men whose understanding of the world cannot be underestimated.
Yoruba: Láyé àtijọ́, ilẹ̀-kú-oótù-o-ò-jí-ire kún fún ènìyàn ọlọ́pọlọ pípé tí òye wọn kọ já sísọ.

English: The wonderful works that these ones left on earth make people call on them for assistance, advice and they see them as one to emulate.
Yoruba: Iṣẹ́ tí àwọn wọ̀nyìí ṣe sílẹ̀ lọ́jọ́ ayé ló sọ wọ́n di ẹni tí ọmọ aráyé ń ké pè fún ìrànlọ́wọ́, ìmọ̀ràn tí wọ́n sí wóò láwò kọ́ṣe.

English: Because of the great works embarked upon by people like these, gave birth to the believe that the soul of the Owner-of-the-universe resides with anybody that shows extravagant character that they are yet to encounter before.
Yoruba: Torí iṣẹ́ takuntakun ọwọ́ọ irú àwọn ènìyàn báwọ̀nyìí ní i má ńmú kí àwọn ọmọ Yoòbá ní gbàgbọ́ pé ẹ̀mí Elédùmarè wà ńnú ẹni kẹ́ni tí í ba ṣe nǹkan àràmàndà tí wọn kò rí rí.

English: They saw that, the authority of the Leader of heaven lives with such persons.
Yoruba: Wọ́n ríi pé, àṣẹ Ọlọfin ọ̀run ń gbé pẹ̀lú wọn.

English: In the second place, our forefathers believes that, some folks cohabitate with the Owner-of-the-universe in heaven, who are his messengers sent to earth from heaven.
Yoruba: Lọ́nà kejì, bàbá ńlá wa gbà pé, àwọn kan ńgbé pẹ̀lú Elédùmarè lọ́run, tí wọ́n jẹ́ òjísẹ́ẹ Elédùà tí ó ńránṣẹ́ wá sílé ayé láti àjùlé ọ̀run.

English: In ancient Ọ̀yọ́, reverence and awe for baby Ṣàngó started on his birthday when his umbilical cord refuse to separate from his abdomen.
Yoruba: Láti ọjọ́ tí abí Ṣàngó tí ìwọ́ rẹ kò já bọ̀ọ̀rọ̀ ni ìlú Ọ̀yọ́ Ilé ti ń fi ìkẹ́ àti àpọ́nlé fún ọmọ tuntun náà.

English: Also Ṣàngó used bitter kola as gun powder, and other miraculous things that he portrayed.
Yoruba: Bákannáà ni Ṣàngó fi orógbó ṣe ẹtù ìbọn, àti àwọn àrà ọwọ́ọ rẹ̀ mìíràn.

English: For this reason, Ṣàngó was regarded as supernatural, an intelligent person who sees wisdom to pick.
Yoruba: Torí ìdí èyí, wọ́n ka Ṣàngó sí alágbára abàmì, ọlọ́gbọ́n ènìyàn tí ó ri ṣà.

English: Same thing applies to Ògún, a great hunter who taught his people the knowledge in iron smelting.
Yoruba: Bẹ́ẹ̀ náà sì ni ti Ògún, ọdẹ tí ó mọ̀ nípa irin ṣíṣe tí ó sì kọ́ àwọn èèyàn rẹ̀.

English: Ọ̀rúnmìlà the father of the Ifá wisdom was human before he became òrìṣà.
Yoruba: Ènìyàn ni Ọ̀rúnmìlà baba ọgbọ́n Ifá náà kí ó tó di ò-rì-ṣà.

English: Even you too can become òrìṣà, if you put in more efforts in what you do, for people of the world to know you for it.
Yoruba: Ìwọ gan-an alára lè di òrìṣà, bí o bá tẹpá mọ́ṣẹ́ ọwọ́ ẹ, kí ọmọ aráyé fi mọ̀ ọ́.

English: What is mammography?
Yoruba: Kí ni mammography?

English: The examination of the breast to quickly ascertain if cancer is present is known as mammography in English language.
Yoruba: Àyèwò ọmú láti tètè mọ̀ bí àrùn jẹjẹrẹ ọmú bá ti wà lára ni wọ́n ń pè ní mammography lédèe Gèésì.

English: Examine the breast, is it the way it should be?
Yoruba: Ẹ yẹ ọmú wò, ṣé ó wà b'ó ṣe yẹ ó wà?

English: You did not notice strange thing?
Yoruba: O kò ṣàkíyèsíi nǹkan àjèjì?

English: Take care of it.
Yoruba: Ẹ tọ́júu rẹ̀ o.

English: You do not know that the breast that protrude out of your body is not for you?
Yoruba: Ẹ ò mọ̀ pé ọmú tí ó sú yọ láyàá yín yẹn kì í ṣe ti yín?

English: You know that?
Yoruba: Ẹ mọ̀ bẹ́ẹ̀?

English: It is for both of us, if one uses it, he/she lives it for the other person to use it.
Yoruba: Àwa méjì la jọ ni í, bí ẹnìkíní bá lò ó, á á gbéeélẹ̀ kẹ́nìkejì ó lò ó.

English: The breast belongs to we and the children.
Yoruba: Àwa àti àwọn ọmọ la ni ọmú.

English: We men and little ones own the breast.
Yoruba: Àwa ọkùnrin àti ọmọọwọ́ ló lọmú.

English: There shouldn’t be any cause for alarm in that.
Yoruba: Àríyànjiyàn ò gbọdọ̀ wáyé nípa ìyẹn.

English: Take care of it for us.
Yoruba: Ẹ bá wa tọ́júu rẹ̀.

English: They have said that men that look at breasts often would live longer than those who don't look at breasts.
Yoruba: Wọ́n kú ti ní ọkùnrin t'ó bá ń wo ọmú lóòrèkóorè yóò pẹ́ láyé ju èyí tí ò wo ọmú.

English: It is ours not yours, we kept it in your possession help us keep it properly in good taste.
Yoruba: Ti wa ni ti yín kọ́, afipamọ́ síi yín lọ́wọ́ ni ẹ bá wa tọ́júu rẹ̀ dáadáa.

English: Only for our children, which we planted on your farm, your breast is what makes them grow.
Yoruba: Àdèfi àwọn ọmọọ wa, tí a gbìn s'ókoo yín, ọyàn yìí ní í jẹ́ wọ́n ta.

English: King Sunny Ade sang a song, he says “give the baby breast (twice), and do not deny a one month baby from suckling the breast, give the baby the breast.”
Yoruba: Sunny Aládé fi k'ọrin, ò ní "ẹ fún ọmọ lọ́yàn (ní ẹ̀mejì), ẹ mọ́ gbọyàn lẹnu ọmọ oṣù kan, ẹ fọ́mọ lọ́yàn mu".

English: You mothers, for this reason, you young women, check your breast often, so that we can treat it early if it happens to be cancer.
Yoruba: Torí ìdí èyí ẹ̀yin màámi, ẹ̀yin sisí mi, ẹ máa yẹ ọyàn an wò, k'á ba tètè gbógun tìí b'ó bá jẹ́ jẹjẹrẹ.

English: Women should eat the vegetable benth, which produces water in excess to curb breast cancer.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀fọ́ọ ebòlò, a ṣ'omi lójú kàrokàro ni kí obìnrin ó máa jẹ̀ láti dínàa jẹjẹrẹ ọmú.

English: The breast is cut off this day if it is affected by cancer, this beauty eat benth vegetable, do not give breast cancer a chance.
Yoruba: Gíge dànù ni à ń gé ọyàn t'ó bá ti ní kòkòròo jẹjẹrẹ lóde ònìí, ẹlẹ́lẹ̀ yìí máa jẹ ẹ̀fọ́ ebòlò má ṣe fún jẹjẹrẹ ọmú láyé.

English: This hip East Nashville cocktail lounge crafts inventive drinks using offbeat, seasonal ingredients, along with draft wines, sophisticated small plates and charcuterie boards.
Yoruba: Yàrá ìgbàlódé ohun mímu àdàlùu East Nashville yìí máa ń ṣe ohun-mimu àrà ọ̀tọ̀ nípa lílo àwọn èròjà tí àkókò-kan-nínú-ọdún, pẹ̀lú ọtí wàìnì tí a pọn lẹ́nu ẹ̀rọ, àwọn àwo kéékèèké tí ò lẹ́lẹ́gbẹ́ àti pátákó ẹran-tútù-sísè.

English: Stylish velvet horseshoe banquettes and brass fixtures add an intimate feel to the upscale space.
Yoruba: Àga bàtà ẹṣin aláràn-án tí ó bá ìgbà mu àti idẹ tí a fi ṣẹ̀ṣọ́ sii lára-á mú u rí bí àyè ọlọ́lá.

English: Great vibe + fantastic, inspired cocktails without all the pretense.
Yoruba: Ìrísí dídára + ńlá, ìmísí ohun mímu àdàlù dáradára tí kò ní ẹ̀tàn nínú rárá.

English: Zagat editor Molly Moker heads to 44 Farms in Cameron, Texas, for a first-hand look at some of the work that goes into raising the ranch's black Angus beef.
Yoruba: Molly Moker tí ó jẹ́ olóòtú Zagat kọrí sí ọ̀dọ̀ àgbẹ̀ 44 ní Cameron, Texas, láti fi ojúkorojú wo díẹ̀ lára iṣẹ́ tí ó ní láti jẹ́ ṣíṣe fún ìgbésókèe ọgbà-ẹranko ẹran màálù dúdú Augus.

English: Rock Stars Redefining the Industry
Yoruba: Àwọn Ìràwọ̀ Akọrin Rock ń fún iléeṣẹ́ náà nítumọ̀ mìíràn

English: Meet the Zagat 30 Under 30 rock stars.
Yoruba: Mọ àwọn ìràwọ̀ Zagat 30 tí kò tó ọmọ ọgbọ̀n ọdún.

English: From a tricycle-riding barista in Boston to an Austin goat farmer who moonlights as a brewer, these visionaries need to be on your must-watch list.
Yoruba: Láti òṣìṣẹ́ẹ kẹ̀kẹ́-ẹlẹ́sẹ̀mẹ́ta kan ni Boston sí àgbé ẹlẹ́ranọ̀sìn ewúrẹ́ ní Autin tí òkìkíi rẹ̀ kàn gẹ́gẹ́ bíi ọ̀pọntí, ó yẹ kí o kíyèsí àwọn ẹni ológo ọjọ́ ọ̀la wọ̀nyí.

English: It's Hawaiian Surf Culture, catch a wave with Big Wave Dave and learn why royalty loved to surf the perfect long waves found on Waikiki beach year round.
Yoruba: Àṣàa Wa-pátákó-lórí-omi Hawaii ni, wá darapọ̀ mọ́ Big Wave Dave kí o mọ ìdíi rẹ̀ tí àwọn ẹni ọlọ́lá fi nífẹ̀ẹ́ sí pátákó-wíwà lórí ìgbì omi ní orí etíkun Waikiki tí ó máa ń wà yíká ọdún.

English: A true surfing ohana, husband, wife, son, and dog........we are super excited to host this experience, we have been hosting on AirBnB since 2014, as hosts we have been sharing the surf experience with all our guests.
Yoruba: Ẹbíi pátákó-wíwà-lórí-ìgbé-omi tòótọ́, ọkọ, aya, ọmọ ọkùnrin, àti ajá………ara wá yá rékọjá gidigidi láti gba àlejò ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ mánigbàgbé yìí, a ti ń gbàlejò lóríi AirBnB láti ọdún-un 2014, gẹ́gẹ́ bíi olùgbàlejò a ti ń ṣàlàyé àwọn ìríríi bí wọ́n ṣe ń wa-pátákó-lórí-ìgbé-omi fún àwọn àlejòo wa.

English: Prying ourselves away from the historic center of Paris, we'll walk into the picturesque Latin Quarter to learn how to burn witches and see a former CIA false-front store where the KGB watched from across the street.
Yoruba: À ń tìkára wa ṣe ìbojúwò kúrò láti àárín-gbùngbùn-un ìlú tí ó kún fún ìtàn-an nì Paris, a óò rìn wọ inú ilée Latin Quarter tí ó rẹwà ní wíwò láti kọ́ bí a ti ṣe ń dáná sun àwọn àjẹ́ àti láti wo ilé ìtajà oníwájú-ìdíbọ́n fún ọ̀tẹlẹ̀múyẹ́ CIA ìgbà kan rí níbi tí KGB ti ń ṣọ́ ojú pópó.

English: While in Fundy, tidal bore rafting is a great water-coaster experience; you can ride 8-foot waves in the Shubenacadie River and then mudslide like a child again on its banks.
Yoruba: Ní Fundy, ọkọ̀-ojú-omi-afátẹ́gùn-sínú-rẹ̀ tí ó ti ìṣàn odò wá jẹ́ ìríríi bèbè omi ńlá kan; o leè wa ọkọ̀ lórí ìgbì-omi ìwọ̀n ẹsẹ̀ 8 ní Odò Shubenacadie tí wà á sì tún yọ̀ nínú ẹrẹ̀ bí ọmọdé ní bèbèe rẹ̀.
